36/* Let's include some standard headers unconditionally as they are
37 already needed by several source files or when some options are
38 enabled/disabled, and it is easy to forget them (some configure
39 options may hide the error).
40 Note: If some source file must not have such a header included
41 (which is very unlikely and probably means something broken in
42 this source file), we should do that with some macro (that would
43 also force to disable incompatible features). */
44
45#if defined (__cplusplus)
46# include <cstdio>
47# include <cstring>
48#else
49# include <stdio.h>
50# include <string.h>
51#endif

54#ifndef MPFR_DONT_USE_FILE
55# define MPFR_USE_FILE
56#endif

59#include <limits.h>

83/* For the definition of MPFR_THREAD_ATTR. GCC/ICC detection macros are
84 no longer used, as they sometimes gave incorrect information about
85 the support of thread-local variables. A configure check is now done. */

120/******************************************************
121 ***************** (U)INTMAX_MAX ********************
122 ******************************************************/
123
124/* Let's try to fix UINTMAX_MAX and INTMAX_MAX if these macros don't work
125 (e.g. with gcc -ansi -pedantic-errors in 32-bit mode under GNU/Linux),
126 see <https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=582698>. */
127#ifdef _MPFR_H_HAVE_INTMAX_T
128# ifdef MPFR_HAVE_INTMAX_MAX
129# define MPFR_UINTMAX_MAX UINTMAX_MAX
130# define MPFR_INTMAX_MAX INTMAX_MAX
131# define MPFR_INTMAX_MIN INTMAX_MIN
132# else
133# define MPFR_UINTMAX_MAX ((uintmax_t) -1)
134# define MPFR_INTMAX_MAX ((intmax_t) (MPFR_UINTMAX_MAX >> 1))
135# define MPFR_INTMAX_MIN (INT_MIN + INT_MAX - MPFR_INTMAX_MAX)
136# endif
137#endif

140/******************************************************
141 ************* Attribute definitions ****************
142 ******************************************************/
143
144#if defined(MPFR_HAVE_NORETURN)
145/* _Noreturn is specified by ISO C11 (Section 6.7.4);
146 in GCC, it is supported as of version 4.7. */
147# define MPFR_NORETURN _Noreturn
148#elif !defined(noreturn)
149/* A noreturn macro could be defined if <stdnoreturn.h> has been included,
150 in which case it would make sense to #define MPFR_NORETURN noreturn.
151 But this is unlikely, as MPFR_HAVE_NORETURN should have been defined
152 in such a case. So, in doubt, let us avoid any code that would use a
153 noreturn macro, since it could be invalid. */
154# if __MPFR_GNUC(3,0) || __MPFR_ICC(8,1,0)
155# define MPFR_NORETURN __attribute__ ((noreturn))
156# elif defined(_MSC_VER) && defined(_WIN32) && (_MSC_VER >= 1200)
157# define MPFR_NORETURN __declspec (noreturn)
158# endif
159#endif
160#ifndef MPFR_NORETURN
161# define MPFR_NORETURN
162#endif
163
164#if __MPFR_GNUC(3,0) || __MPFR_ICC(8,1,0)
165# define MPFR_CONST_ATTR __attribute__ ((const))
166#else
167# define MPFR_CONST_ATTR
168#endif
169
170#if __MPFR_GNUC(3,0) || __MPFR_ICC(8,1,0)
171# define MPFR_PURE_FUNCTION_ATTR __attribute__ ((pure))
172#else
173# define MPFR_PURE_FUNCTION_ATTR
174#endif
175
176/* The hot attribute on a function is used to inform the compiler
177 that the function is a hot spot of the compiled program. */
178#if __MPFR_GNUC(4,3)
179# define MPFR_HOT_FUNCTION_ATTR __attribute__ ((hot))
180#else
181# define MPFR_HOT_FUNCTION_ATTR
182#endif
183
184/* The cold attribute on functions is used to inform the compiler
185 that the function is unlikely to be executed. */
186#if __MPFR_GNUC(4,3)
187# define MPFR_COLD_FUNCTION_ATTR __attribute__ ((cold))
188#else
189# define MPFR_COLD_FUNCTION_ATTR
190#endif
191
192/* add MPFR_MAYBE_UNUSED after a variable declaration to avoid compiler
193 warnings if it is not used */
194#if __MPFR_GNUC(3,4)
195#define MPFR_MAYBE_UNUSED __attribute__ ((unused))
196#else
197#define MPFR_MAYBE_UNUSED
198#endif

210#if defined(WANT_SHARED_CACHE)
211# define MPFR_CACHE_ATTR
212#else
213# define MPFR_CACHE_ATTR MPFR_THREAD_ATTR

216struct __gmpfr_cache_s {
217 mpfr_t x;
218 int inexact;
219 int (*func)(mpfr_ptr, mpfr_rnd_t);
220 MPFR_DEFERRED_INIT_SLAVE_DECL()
221 MPFR_LOCK_DECL(lock)
222};
223typedef struct __gmpfr_cache_s mpfr_cache_t[1];
224typedef struct __gmpfr_cache_s *mpfr_cache_ptr;
225
226#if __GMP_LIBGMP_DLL
227# define MPFR_WIN_THREAD_SAFE_DLL 1
228#endif
229
230#if defined(__MPFR_WITHIN_MPFR) || !defined(MPFR_WIN_THREAD_SAFE_DLL)
231extern MPFR_THREAD_ATTR mpfr_flags_t __gmpfr_flags;
232extern MPFR_THREAD_ATTR mpfr_exp_t __gmpfr_emin;
233extern MPFR_THREAD_ATTR mpfr_exp_t __gmpfr_emax;
234extern MPFR_THREAD_ATTR mpfr_prec_t __gmpfr_default_fp_bit_precision;
235extern MPFR_THREAD_ATTR mpfr_rnd_t __gmpfr_default_rounding_mode;
236extern MPFR_CACHE_ATTR mpfr_cache_t __gmpfr_cache_const_euler;
237extern MPFR_CACHE_ATTR mpfr_cache_t __gmpfr_cache_const_catalan;
238# ifndef MPFR_USE_LOGGING
239extern MPFR_CACHE_ATTR mpfr_cache_t __gmpfr_cache_const_pi;
240extern MPFR_CACHE_ATTR mpfr_cache_t __gmpfr_cache_const_log2;
241# else
242/* Two constants are used by the logging functions (via mpfr_fprintf,
243 then mpfr_log, for the base conversion): pi and log(2). Since the
244 mpfr_cache function isn't re-entrant when working on the same cache,
245 we need to define two caches for each constant. */
246extern MPFR_CACHE_ATTR mpfr_cache_t __gmpfr_normal_pi;
247extern MPFR_CACHE_ATTR mpfr_cache_t __gmpfr_normal_log2;
248extern MPFR_CACHE_ATTR mpfr_cache_t __gmpfr_logging_pi;
249extern MPFR_CACHE_ATTR mpfr_cache_t __gmpfr_logging_log2;
250extern MPFR_CACHE_ATTR mpfr_cache_ptr __gmpfr_cache_const_pi;
251extern MPFR_CACHE_ATTR mpfr_cache_ptr __gmpfr_cache_const_log2;
252# endif
253#endif
254
255#ifdef MPFR_WIN_THREAD_SAFE_DLL
256# define MPFR_MAKE_VARFCT(T,N) T * N ## _f (void) { return &N; }
257__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_flags_t * __gmpfr_flags_f (void);
258__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_exp_t * __gmpfr_emin_f (void);
259__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_exp_t * __gmpfr_emax_f (void);
260__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_prec_t * __gmpfr_default_fp_bit_precision_f (void);
261__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_rnd_t * __gmpfr_default_rounding_mode_f (void);
262__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_cache_t * __gmpfr_cache_const_euler_f (void);
263__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_cache_t * __gmpfr_cache_const_catalan_f (void);
264# ifndef MPFR_USE_LOGGING
265__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_cache_t * __gmpfr_cache_const_pi_f (void);
266__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_cache_t * __gmpfr_cache_const_log2_f (void);
267# else
268__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_cache_t * __gmpfr_normal_pi_f (void);
269__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_cache_t * __gmpfr_normal_log2_f (void);
270__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_cache_t * __gmpfr_logging_pi_f (void);
271__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_cache_t * __gmpfr_logging_log2_f (void);
272__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_cache_ptr * __gmpfr_cache_const_pi_f (void);
273__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_cache_ptr * __gmpfr_cache_const_log2_f (void);
274# endif
275# ifndef __MPFR_WITHIN_MPFR
276# define __gmpfr_flags (*__gmpfr_flags_f())
277# define __gmpfr_emin (*__gmpfr_emin_f())
278# define __gmpfr_emax (*__gmpfr_emax_f())
279# define __gmpfr_default_fp_bit_precision (*__gmpfr_default_fp_bit_precision_f())
280# define __gmpfr_default_rounding_mode (*__gmpfr_default_rounding_mode_f())
281# define __gmpfr_cache_const_euler (*__gmpfr_cache_const_euler_f())
282# define __gmpfr_cache_const_catalan (*__gmpfr_cache_const_catalan_f())
283# ifndef MPFR_USE_LOGGING
284# define __gmpfr_cache_const_pi (*__gmpfr_cache_const_pi_f())
285# define __gmpfr_cache_const_log2 (*__gmpfr_cache_const_log2_f())
286# else
287# define __gmpfr_normal_pi (*__gmpfr_normal_pi_f())
288# define __gmpfr_logging_pi (*__gmpfr_logging_pi_f())
289# define __gmpfr_logging_log2 (*__gmpfr_logging_log2_f())
290# define __gmpfr_cache_const_pi (*__gmpfr_cache_const_pi_f())
291# define __gmpfr_cache_const_log2 (*__gmpfr_cache_const_log2_f())
292# endif
293# endif
294#else
295# define MPFR_MAKE_VARFCT(T,N)
296#endif
297
298# define MPFR_THREAD_VAR(T,N,V) \
299 MPFR_THREAD_ATTR T N = (V); \
300 MPFR_MAKE_VARFCT (T,N)
301
302#define BASE_MAX 62
303__MPFR_DECLSPEC extern const __mpfr_struct __gmpfr_l2b[BASE_MAX-1][2];

305/* Note: do not use the following values when they can be outside the
306 current exponent range, e.g. when the exponent range has not been
307 extended yet; under such a condition, they can be used only in
308 mpfr_cmpabs. */
309__MPFR_DECLSPEC extern const mpfr_t __gmpfr_one;
310__MPFR_DECLSPEC extern const mpfr_t __gmpfr_two;
311__MPFR_DECLSPEC extern const mpfr_t __gmpfr_four;
312__MPFR_DECLSPEC extern const mpfr_t __gmpfr_mone;
313__MPFR_DECLSPEC extern const mpfr_t __gmpfr_const_log2_RNDD;
314__MPFR_DECLSPEC extern const mpfr_t __gmpfr_const_log2_RNDU;

320/* Replace some common functions for direct access to the global vars.
321 The casts prevent these macros from being used as a lvalue (and this
322 method makes sure that the expressions have the correct type). */
323
324#define mpfr_get_emin() ((mpfr_exp_t) __gmpfr_emin)
325#define mpfr_get_emax() ((mpfr_exp_t) __gmpfr_emax)
326#define mpfr_get_default_rounding_mode() \
327 ((mpfr_rnd_t) __gmpfr_default_rounding_mode)
328#define mpfr_get_default_prec() \
329 ((mpfr_prec_t) __gmpfr_default_fp_bit_precision)
330
331/* Flags related macros. */
332/* Note: Function-like macros that modify __gmpfr_flags are not defined
333 because of the risk to break the sequence point rules if two such
334 macros are used in the same expression (without a sequence point
335 between). For instance, mpfr_sgn currently uses mpfr_set_erangeflag,
336 which mustn't be implemented as a macro for this reason. */
337
338#define mpfr_flags_test(mask) \
339 (__gmpfr_flags & (mpfr_flags_t) (mask))
340
341#if MPFR_FLAGS_ALL <= INT_MAX
342#define mpfr_underflow_p() \
343 ((int) (__gmpfr_flags & MPFR_FLAGS_UNDERFLOW))
344#define mpfr_overflow_p() \
345 ((int) (__gmpfr_flags & MPFR_FLAGS_OVERFLOW))
346#define mpfr_nanflag_p() \
347 ((int) (__gmpfr_flags & MPFR_FLAGS_NAN))
348#define mpfr_inexflag_p() \
349 ((int) (__gmpfr_flags & MPFR_FLAGS_INEXACT))
350#define mpfr_erangeflag_p() \
351 ((int) (__gmpfr_flags & MPFR_FLAGS_ERANGE))
352#define mpfr_divby0_p() \
353 ((int) (__gmpfr_flags & MPFR_FLAGS_DIVBY0))
354#endif
355
356/* Use a do-while statement for the following macros in order to prevent
357 one from using them in an expression, as the sequence point rules could
358 be broken if __gmpfr_flags is assigned twice in the same expression
359 (via macro expansions). For instance, the mpfr_sgn macro currently uses
360 mpfr_set_erangeflag, which mustn't be implemented as a function-like
361 macro for this reason. It is not clear whether an expression with
362 sequence points, like (void) (0, __gmpfr_flags = 0), would avoid UB. */
363#define MPFR_CLEAR_FLAGS() \
364 do __gmpfr_flags = 0; while (0)
365#define MPFR_CLEAR_UNDERFLOW() \
366 do __gmpfr_flags &= MPFR_FLAGS_ALL ^ MPFR_FLAGS_UNDERFLOW; while (0)
367#define MPFR_CLEAR_OVERFLOW() \
368 do __gmpfr_flags &= MPFR_FLAGS_ALL ^ MPFR_FLAGS_OVERFLOW; while (0)
369#define MPFR_CLEAR_DIVBY0() \
370 do __gmpfr_flags &= MPFR_FLAGS_ALL ^ MPFR_FLAGS_DIVBY0; while (0)
371#define MPFR_CLEAR_NANFLAG() \
372 do __gmpfr_flags &= MPFR_FLAGS_ALL ^ MPFR_FLAGS_NAN; while (0)
373#define MPFR_CLEAR_INEXFLAG() \
374 do __gmpfr_flags &= MPFR_FLAGS_ALL ^ MPFR_FLAGS_INEXACT; while (0)
375#define MPFR_CLEAR_ERANGEFLAG() \
376 do __gmpfr_flags &= MPFR_FLAGS_ALL ^ MPFR_FLAGS_ERANGE; while (0)
377#define MPFR_SET_UNDERFLOW() \
378 do __gmpfr_flags |= MPFR_FLAGS_UNDERFLOW; while (0)
379#define MPFR_SET_OVERFLOW() \
380 do __gmpfr_flags |= MPFR_FLAGS_OVERFLOW; while (0)
381#define MPFR_SET_DIVBY0() \
382 do __gmpfr_flags |= MPFR_FLAGS_DIVBY0; while (0)
383#define MPFR_SET_NANFLAG() \
384 do __gmpfr_flags |= MPFR_FLAGS_NAN; while (0)
385#define MPFR_SET_INEXFLAG() \
386 do __gmpfr_flags |= MPFR_FLAGS_INEXACT; while (0)
387#define MPFR_SET_ERANGEFLAG() \
388 do __gmpfr_flags |= MPFR_FLAGS_ERANGE; while (0)
389
390/* Testing an exception flag correctly is tricky. There are mainly two
391 pitfalls: First, one needs to remember to clear the corresponding
392 flag, in case it was set before the function call or during some
393 intermediate computations (in practice, one can clear all the flags).
394 Secondly, one needs to test the flag early enough, i.e. before it
395 can be modified by another function. Moreover, it is quite difficult
396 (if not impossible) to reliably check problems with "make check". To
397 avoid these pitfalls, it is recommended to use the following macros.
398 Other use of the exception-flag predicate functions/macros will be
399 detected by mpfrlint.
400 Note: _op can be either a statement or an expression.
401 MPFR_BLOCK_EXCEP should be used only inside a block; it is useful to
402 detect some exception in order to exit the block as soon as possible. */
403#define MPFR_BLOCK_DECL(_flags) mpfr_flags_t _flags
404/* The (void) (_flags) makes sure that _flags is read at least once (it
405 makes sense to use MPFR_BLOCK while _flags will never be read in the
406 source, so that we wish to avoid the corresponding warning). */
407#define MPFR_BLOCK(_flags,_op) \
408 do \
409 { \
410 MPFR_CLEAR_FLAGS (); \
411 _op; \
412 (_flags) = __gmpfr_flags; \
413 (void) (_flags); \
414 } \
415 while (0)
416#define MPFR_BLOCK_TEST(_flags,_f) MPFR_UNLIKELY ((_flags) & (_f))
417#define MPFR_BLOCK_EXCEP (__gmpfr_flags & (MPFR_FLAGS_UNDERFLOW | \
418 MPFR_FLAGS_OVERFLOW | \
419 MPFR_FLAGS_DIVBY0 | \
420 MPFR_FLAGS_NAN))
421/* Let's use a MPFR_ prefix, because e.g. OVERFLOW is defined by glibc's
422 math.h, though this is not a reserved identifier! */
423#define MPFR_UNDERFLOW(_flags) MPFR_BLOCK_TEST (_flags, MPFR_FLAGS_UNDERFLOW)
424#define MPFR_OVERFLOW(_flags) MPFR_BLOCK_TEST (_flags, MPFR_FLAGS_OVERFLOW)
425#define MPFR_NANFLAG(_flags) MPFR_BLOCK_TEST (_flags, MPFR_FLAGS_NAN)
426#define MPFR_INEXFLAG(_flags) MPFR_BLOCK_TEST (_flags, MPFR_FLAGS_INEXACT)
427#define MPFR_ERANGEFLAG(_flags) MPFR_BLOCK_TEST (_flags, MPFR_FLAGS_ERANGE)
428#define MPFR_DIVBY0(_flags) MPFR_BLOCK_TEST (_flags, MPFR_FLAGS_DIVBY0)
429
430
431/******************************************************
432 ******************* Assertions *********************
433 ******************************************************/
434
435/* MPFR_WANT_ASSERT can take 4 values (the default value is 0):
436 -1 (or below): Do not check any assertion. Discouraged, in particular
437 for a shared library (for time-critical applications, LTO with a
438 static library should also be used anyway).
439 0: Check normal assertions.
440 1: Check debugging assertions too.
441 2 (or above): Additional checks that may take time. For instance,
442 some functions may be tested by using two different implementations
443 and comparing the results.
444*/
445
446/* Note: do not use GMP macros ASSERT_ALWAYS and ASSERT as they are not
447 expressions, and as a consequence, they cannot be used in a for(),
448 with a comma operator and so on. */
449
450/* MPFR_ASSERTN(expr): assertions that should normally be checked,
451 otherwise give a hint to the compiler.
452 MPFR_ASSERTD(expr): assertions that should be checked when testing,
453 otherwise give a hint to the compiler.
454 MPFR_DBGRES(assignment): to be used when the result is tested only
455 in an MPFR_ASSERTD expression (in order to avoid a warning, e.g.
456 with GCC's -Wunused-but-set-variable, in non-debug mode).
457 Note: Evaluating expr might yield side effects, but such side effects
458 must not change the results (except by yielding an assertion failure).
459*/
460#ifndef MPFR_WANT_ASSERT
461# define MPFR_WANT_ASSERT 0
462#endif
463
464#if MPFR_WANT_ASSERT < 0
465# undef MPFR_EXP_CHECK
466# define MPFR_ASSERTN(expr) MPFR_ASSUME (expr)
467#else
468# define MPFR_ASSERTN(expr) \
469 ((void) ((MPFR_LIKELY(expr)) || (ASSERT_FAIL(expr),MPFR_ASSUME(expr),0)))
470/* Some explanations: mpfr_assert_fail is not marked as "no return",
471 so that ((void) ((MPFR_LIKELY(expr)) || (ASSERT_FAIL(expr),0)))
472 cannot be a way to tell the compiler that after this code, expr is
473 necessarily true. The MPFR_ASSUME(expr) is a way to tell the compiler
474 that if expr is false, then ASSERT_FAIL(expr) does not return
475 (otherwise they would be a contradiction / UB when MPFR_ASSUME(expr)
476 is reached). Such information is useful to avoid warnings like those
477 from -Wmaybe-uninitialized, e.g. in tests/turandom.c r11663 on t[0]
478 from "mpfr_equal_p (y, t[0])".
479 TODO: Remove the MPFR_ASSUME(expr) once mpfr_assert_fail is marked as
480 "no return".
481 */
482#endif
483
484#if MPFR_WANT_ASSERT > 0
485# define MPFR_EXP_CHECK 1
486# define MPFR_ASSERTD(expr) MPFR_ASSERTN (expr)
487# define MPFR_DBGRES(A) (A)
488#else
489# define MPFR_ASSERTD(expr) MPFR_ASSUME (expr)
490# define MPFR_DBGRES(A) ((void) (A))
491#endif
492
493/* MPFR_ASSUME is like assert(), but it is a hint to a compiler about a
494 statement of fact in a function call free expression, which allows
495 the compiler to generate better machine code.
496 __builtin_unreachable has been introduced in GCC 4.5 but it works
497 fine since 4.8 only (before it may generate unoptimized code if there
498 are more than one decision).
499 Note:
500 The goal of MPFR_ASSUME() is to allow the compiler to optimize even
501 more. Thus we need to make sure that its use in MPFR will never yield
502 code generation. Since MPFR_ASSUME() may be used by MPFR_ASSERTN()
503 and MPFR_ASSERTD(), whose expression might have side effects, we need
504 to make sure that the expression x is not evaluated in such a case.
505 This is done with __builtin_constant_p (!!(x) || !(x)), whose value
506 is 0 if x has side effects, and normally 1 if the compiler knows that
507 x has no side effects (since here, it can deduce that !!(x) || !(x)
508 is equivalent to the constant 1). In the former case, MPFR_ASSUME(x)
509 will give (void) 0, and in the latter case, it will give:
510 (x) ? (void) 0 : __builtin_unreachable()
511 In the development code, it is better to use MPFR_ASSERTD than
512 MPFR_ASSUME, since it'll check if the condition is true in debug
513 build.
514*/
515#if defined(MPFR_HAVE_BUILTIN_UNREACHABLE) && __MPFR_GNUC(4, 8)
516# define MPFR_ASSUME(x) \
517 (! __builtin_constant_p (!!(x) || !(x)) || (x) ? \
518 (void) 0 : __builtin_unreachable())
519#elif defined(_MSC_VER)
520# define MPFR_ASSUME(x) __assume(x)
521#else
522# define MPFR_ASSUME(x) ((void) 0)
523#endif
524
525#include "mpfr-sassert.h"
526
527/* Code to deal with impossible, for functions returning an int.
528 The "return 0;" avoids an error with current GCC versions and
529 "-Werror=return-type".
530 WARNING: It doesn't use do { } while (0) for Insure++ */
531#if defined(HAVE_BUILTIN_UNREACHABLE)
532# define MPFR_RET_NEVER_GO_HERE() do { __builtin_unreachable(); } while (0)
533#else
534# define MPFR_RET_NEVER_GO_HERE() do { MPFR_ASSERTN(0); return 0; } while (0)
535#endif
536
537
538/******************************************************
539 ******************* Warnings ***********************
540 ******************************************************/
541
542/* MPFR_WARNING is no longer useful, but let's keep the macro in case
543 it needs to be used again in the future. */
544
545#ifdef MPFR_USE_WARNINGS
546# define MPFR_WARNING(W) \
547 do \
548 { \
549 char *q = getenv ("MPFR_QUIET"); \
550 if (q == NULL || *q == 0) \
551 fprintf (stderr, "MPFR: %s\n", W); \
552 } \
553 while (0)
554#else
555# define MPFR_WARNING(W) ((void) 0)
556#endif
557
558
559/******************************************************
560 ***************** double macros ********************
561 ******************************************************/
562
563/* Precision used for lower precision computations */
564#define MPFR_SMALL_PRECISION 32
565
566/* Definition of constants */
567#define LOG2 0.69314718055994528622 /* log(2) rounded to zero on 53 bits */
568
569/* MPFR_DOUBLE_SPEC = 1 if the C type 'double' corresponds to IEEE-754
570 double precision, 0 if it doesn't, and undefined if one doesn't know.
571 On all the tested machines, MPFR_DOUBLE_SPEC = 1. To have this macro
572 defined here, #include <float.h> is needed. If need be, other values
573 could be defined for other specs (once they are known). */
574#if !defined(MPFR_DOUBLE_SPEC) && defined(FLT_RADIX) && \
575 defined(DBL_MANT_DIG) && defined(DBL_MIN_EXP) && defined(DBL_MAX_EXP)
576# if FLT_RADIX == 2 && DBL_MANT_DIG == 53 && \
577 DBL_MIN_EXP == -1021 && DBL_MAX_EXP == 1024
578# define MPFR_DOUBLE_SPEC 1
579# else
580# define MPFR_DOUBLE_SPEC 0
581# endif
582#endif
583
584/* With -DMPFR_DISABLE_IEEE_FLOATS, exercise non IEEE floats */
585#ifdef MPFR_DISABLE_IEEE_FLOATS
586# ifdef _MPFR_IEEE_FLOATS
587# undef _MPFR_IEEE_FLOATS
588# endif
589# define _MPFR_IEEE_FLOATS 0
590#endif
591
592#ifndef IEEE_DBL_MANT_DIG
593#define IEEE_DBL_MANT_DIG 53
594#endif
595#define MPFR_LIMBS_PER_DOUBLE ((IEEE_DBL_MANT_DIG-1)/GMP_NUMB_BITS+1)
596
597#ifndef IEEE_FLT_MANT_DIG
598#define IEEE_FLT_MANT_DIG 24
599#endif
600#define MPFR_LIMBS_PER_FLT ((IEEE_FLT_MANT_DIG-1)/GMP_NUMB_BITS+1)
601
602/* Visual C++ doesn't support +1.0/0.0, -1.0/0.0 and 0.0/0.0
603 at compile time.
604 Clang with -fsanitize=undefined is a bit similar due to a bug:
605 https://llvm.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=17381 (fixed on 2015-12-03)
606 but even without its sanitizer, it may be better to use the
607 double_zero version until IEEE 754 division by zero is properly
608 supported:
609 https://llvm.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=17005
610 Note: DBL_NAN is 0/0, thus its value is a quiet NaN (qNAN).
611*/
612#if (defined(_MSC_VER) && defined(_WIN32) && (_MSC_VER >= 1200)) || \
613 defined(__clang__)
614static double double_zero = 0.0;
615# define DBL_NAN (double_zero/double_zero)
616# define DBL_POS_INF ((double) 1.0/double_zero)
617# define DBL_NEG_INF ((double)-1.0/double_zero)
618# define DBL_NEG_ZERO (-double_zero)
619#else
620# define DBL_POS_INF ((double) 1.0/0.0)
621# define DBL_NEG_INF ((double)-1.0/0.0)
622# define DBL_NAN ((double) 0.0/0.0)
623# define DBL_NEG_ZERO (-0.0)
624#endif
625
626/* Note: In the past, there was specific code for _MPFR_IEEE_FLOATS, which
627 was based on NaN and Inf memory representations. This code was breaking
628 the aliasing rules (see ISO C99, 6.5#6 and 6.5#7 on the effective type)
629 and for this reason it did not behave correctly with GCC 4.5.0 20091119.
630 The code needed a memory transfer and was probably not better than the
631 macros below with a good compiler (a fix based on the NaN / Inf memory
632 representation would be even worse due to C limitations), and this code
633 could be selected only when MPFR was built with --with-gmp-build, thus
634 introducing a difference (bad for maintaining/testing MPFR); therefore
635 it has been removed. The old code required that the argument x be an
636 lvalue of type double. We still require that, in case one would need
637 to change the macros below, e.g. for some broken compiler. But the
638 LVALUE(x) condition could be removed if really necessary. */
639/* Below, the &(x) == &(x) || &(x) != &(x) allows to make sure that x
640 is a lvalue without (probably) any warning from the compiler. The
641 &(x) != &(x) is needed to avoid a failure under Mac OS X 10.4.11
642 (with Xcode 2.4.1, i.e. the latest one). */
643#define LVALUE(x) (&(x) == &(x) || &(x) != &(x))
644#define DOUBLE_ISINF(x) (LVALUE(x) && ((x) > DBL_MAX || (x) < -DBL_MAX))
645/* The DOUBLE_ISNAN(x) macro is also valid on long double x
646 (assuming that the compiler isn't too broken). */
647#ifdef MPFR_NANISNAN
648/* Avoid MIPSpro / IRIX64 / gcc -ffast-math (incorrect) optimizations.
649 The + must not be replaced by a ||. With gcc -ffast-math, NaN is
650 regarded as a positive number or something like that; the second
651 test catches this case.
652 [2016-03-01] Various tests now fail with gcc -ffast-math or just
653 -ffinite-math-only; such options are not supported, but this makes
654 difficult to test MPFR assuming x == x optimization to 1. Anyway
655 support of functions/tests of using native FP and special values for
656 non-IEEE-754 environment will always be on a case-by-case basis. */
657# define DOUBLE_ISNAN(x) \
658 (LVALUE(x) && !((((x) >= 0.0) + ((x) <= 0.0)) && -(x)*(x) <= 0.0))
659#else
660# define DOUBLE_ISNAN(x) (LVALUE(x) && (x) != (x))
661#endif
662
663
664/******************************************************
665 ********** long double macros and typedef **********
666 ******************************************************/
667
668/* We try to get the exact value of the precision of long double
669 (provided by the implementation) in order to provide correct
670 rounding in this case (not guaranteed if the C implementation
671 does not have an adequate long double arithmetic). Note that
672 it may be lower than the precision of some numbers that can
673 be represented in a long double; e.g. on FreeBSD/x86, it is
674 53 because the processor is configured to round in double
675 precision (even when using the long double type -- this is a
676 limitation of the x87 arithmetic), and on Mac OS X, it is 106
677 because the implementation is a double-double arithmetic.
678 Otherwise (e.g. in base 10), we get an upper bound of the
679 precision, and correct rounding isn't currently provided.
680*/
681
682/* Definitions are enabled only if <float.h> is included. */
683#if defined (FLT_RADIX)
684
685#if defined(LDBL_MANT_DIG) && FLT_RADIX == 2
686# define MPFR_LDBL_MANT_DIG LDBL_MANT_DIG
687#else
688# define MPFR_LDBL_MANT_DIG \
689 (sizeof(long double)*GMP_NUMB_BITS/sizeof(mp_limb_t))
690#endif
691#define MPFR_LIMBS_PER_LONG_DOUBLE \
692 ((sizeof(long double)-1)/sizeof(mp_limb_t)+1)
693
694/* LONGDOUBLE_NAN_ACTION executes the code "action" if x is a NaN. */
695
696/* On hppa2.0n-hp-hpux10 with the unbundled HP cc, the test x!=x on a NaN
697 has been seen false, meaning NaNs are not detected. This seemed to
698 happen only after other comparisons, not sure what's really going on. In
699 any case we can pick apart the bytes to identify a NaN. */
700#ifdef HAVE_LDOUBLE_IEEE_QUAD_BIG
701# define LONGDOUBLE_NAN_ACTION(x, action) \
702 do { \
703 union { \
704 long double ld; \
705 struct { \
706 unsigned int sign : 1; \
707 unsigned int exp : 15; \
708 unsigned int man3 : 16; \
709 unsigned int man2 : 32; \
710 unsigned int man1 : 32; \
711 unsigned int man0 : 32; \
712 } s; \
713 } u; \
714 u.ld = (x); \
715 if (u.s.exp == 0x7FFFL \
716 && (u.s.man0 | u.s.man1 | u.s.man2 | u.s.man3) != 0) \
717 { action; } \
718 } while (0)
719#endif
720
721#ifdef HAVE_LDOUBLE_IEEE_QUAD_LITTLE
722# define LONGDOUBLE_NAN_ACTION(x, action) \
723 do { \
724 union { \
725 long double ld; \
726 struct { \
727 unsigned int man0 : 32; \
728 unsigned int man1 : 32; \
729 unsigned int man2 : 32; \
730 unsigned int man3 : 16; \
731 unsigned int exp : 15; \
732 unsigned int sign : 1; \
733 } s; \
734 } u; \
735 u.ld = (x); \
736 if (u.s.exp == 0x7FFFL \
737 && (u.s.man0 | u.s.man1 | u.s.man2 | u.s.man3) != 0) \
738 { action; } \
739 } while (0)
740#endif
741
742/* Under IEEE rules, NaN is not equal to anything, including itself.
743 "volatile" here stops "cc" on mips64-sgi-irix6.5 from optimizing away
744 x!=x. */
745#ifndef LONGDOUBLE_NAN_ACTION
746# define LONGDOUBLE_NAN_ACTION(x, action) \
747 do { \
748 volatile long double __x = LONGDOUBLE_VOLATILE (x); \
749 if ((x) != __x) \
750 { action; } \
751 } while (0)
752# define WANT_LONGDOUBLE_VOLATILE 1
753#endif
754
755/* If we don't have a proper "volatile" then volatile is #defined to empty,
756 in this case call through an external function to stop the compiler
757 optimizing anything. */
758#ifdef WANT_LONGDOUBLE_VOLATILE
759# ifdef volatile
760__MPFR_DECLSPEC long double
761 __gmpfr_longdouble_volatile (long double) MPFR_CONST_ATTR;
762# define LONGDOUBLE_VOLATILE(x) (__gmpfr_longdouble_volatile (x))
763# define WANT_GMPFR_LONGDOUBLE_VOLATILE 1
764# else
765# define LONGDOUBLE_VOLATILE(x) (x)
766# endif
767#endif
768
769/* Some special case for IEEE_EXT Litle Endian */
770#if HAVE_LDOUBLE_IEEE_EXT_LITTLE
771
772typedef union {
773 long double ld;
774 struct {
775 unsigned int manl : 32;
776 unsigned int manh : 32;
777 unsigned int expl : 8 ;
778 unsigned int exph : 7;
779 unsigned int sign : 1;
780 } s;
781} mpfr_long_double_t;
782
783/* #undef MPFR_LDBL_MANT_DIG */
784#undef MPFR_LIMBS_PER_LONG_DOUBLE
785/* #define MPFR_LDBL_MANT_DIG 64 */
786#define MPFR_LIMBS_PER_LONG_DOUBLE ((64-1)/GMP_NUMB_BITS+1)
787
788#endif
789
790#endif /* long double macros and typedef */
791
792
793/******************************************************
794 **************** __float128 support ****************
795 ******************************************************/
796
797/* This is standardized by IEEE 754-2008. */
798#define IEEE_FLOAT128_MANT_DIG 113
799
800
801/******************************************************
802 **************** _Decimal64 support ****************
803 ******************************************************/
804
805#ifdef MPFR_WANT_DECIMAL_FLOATS
806/* to cast between binary64 and decimal64 */
807union ieee_double_decimal64 { double d; _Decimal64 d64; };
808#endif /* MPFR_WANT_DECIMAL_FLOATS */
809
810
811/******************************************************
812 **************** mpfr_t properties *****************
813 ******************************************************/
814
815#define MPFR_PREC_COND(p) ((p) >= MPFR_PREC_MIN && (p) <= MPFR_PREC_MAX)
816#define MPFR_PREC_IN_RANGE(p) (MPFR_ASSERTD (MPFR_PREC_COND(p)), (p))
817
818/* In the following macro, p is usually a mpfr_prec_t, but this macro
819 works with other integer types (without integer overflow). Checking
820 that p >= 1 in debug mode is useful here because this macro can be
821 used on a computed precision (in particular, this formula does not
822 work for a degenerate case p = 0, and could give different results
823 on different platforms). But let us not use an assertion checking
824 in the MPFR_LAST_LIMB() and MPFR_LIMB_SIZE() macros below to avoid
825 too much expansion for assertions (in practice, this should be a
826 problem just when testing MPFR with the --enable-assert configure
827 option and the -ansi -pedantic-errors gcc compiler flags). */
828#define MPFR_PREC2LIMBS(p) \
829 (MPFR_ASSERTD ((p) >= 1), ((p) - 1) / GMP_NUMB_BITS + 1)
830
831#define MPFR_PREC(x) ((x)->_mpfr_prec)
832#define MPFR_EXP(x) ((x)->_mpfr_exp)
833#define MPFR_MANT(x) ((x)->_mpfr_d)
834#define MPFR_GET_PREC(x) MPFR_PREC_IN_RANGE (MPFR_PREC (x))
835#define MPFR_LAST_LIMB(x) ((MPFR_GET_PREC (x) - 1) / GMP_NUMB_BITS)
836#define MPFR_LIMB_SIZE(x) (MPFR_LAST_LIMB (x) + 1)
837
838
839/******************************************************
840 *************** Exponent properties ****************
841 ******************************************************/
842
843/* Limits of the mpfr_exp_t type (NOT those of valid exponent values).
844 These macros can be used in preprocessor directives. */
845#if _MPFR_EXP_FORMAT == 1
846# define MPFR_EXP_MAX (SHRT_MAX)
847# define MPFR_EXP_MIN (SHRT_MIN)
848#elif _MPFR_EXP_FORMAT == 2
849# define MPFR_EXP_MAX (INT_MAX)
850# define MPFR_EXP_MIN (INT_MIN)
851#elif _MPFR_EXP_FORMAT == 3
852# define MPFR_EXP_MAX (LONG_MAX)
853# define MPFR_EXP_MIN (LONG_MIN)
854#elif _MPFR_EXP_FORMAT == 4
855/* Note: MPFR_EXP_MAX and MPFR_EXP_MIN must not be used in #if directives
856 if _MPFR_EXP_FORMAT == 4 and MPFR_HAVE_INTMAX_MAX is not defined. */
857# define MPFR_EXP_MAX (MPFR_INTMAX_MAX)
858# define MPFR_EXP_MIN (MPFR_INTMAX_MIN)
859#else
860# error "Invalid MPFR Exp format"
861#endif
862
863/* Before doing a cast to mpfr_uexp_t, make sure that the value is
864 nonnegative. */
865#define MPFR_UEXP(X) (MPFR_ASSERTD ((X) >= 0), (mpfr_uexp_t) (X))
866
867#if _MPFR_EXP_FORMAT <= 3
868typedef long mpfr_eexp_t;
869typedef unsigned long mpfr_ueexp_t;
870# define mpfr_get_exp_t(x,r) mpfr_get_si((x),(r))
871# define mpfr_set_exp_t(x,e,r) mpfr_set_si((x),(e),(r))
872# define MPFR_EXP_FSPEC "l"
873#else
874typedef intmax_t mpfr_eexp_t;
875typedef uintmax_t mpfr_ueexp_t;
876# define mpfr_get_exp_t(x,r) mpfr_get_sj((x),(r))
877# define mpfr_set_exp_t(x,e,r) mpfr_set_sj((x),(e),(r))
878# define MPFR_EXP_FSPEC "j"
879#endif
880
881/* Size of mpfr_exp_t in limbs */
882#define MPFR_EXP_LIMB_SIZE \
883 ((sizeof (mpfr_exp_t) - 1) / MPFR_BYTES_PER_MP_LIMB + 1)
884
885/* Invalid exponent value (to track bugs...) */
886#define MPFR_EXP_INVALID \
887 ((mpfr_exp_t) 1 << (GMP_NUMB_BITS*sizeof(mpfr_exp_t)/sizeof(mp_limb_t)-2))
888
889/* Definition of the exponent limits for MPFR numbers.
890 * These limits are chosen so that if e is such an exponent, then 2e-1 and
891 * 2e+1 are representable. This is useful for intermediate computations,
892 * in particular the multiplication.
893 */
894#undef MPFR_EMIN_MIN
895#undef MPFR_EMIN_MAX
896#undef MPFR_EMAX_MIN
897#undef MPFR_EMAX_MAX
898#define MPFR_EMIN_MIN (1-MPFR_EXP_INVALID)
899#define MPFR_EMIN_MAX (MPFR_EXP_INVALID-1)
900#define MPFR_EMAX_MIN (1-MPFR_EXP_INVALID)
901#define MPFR_EMAX_MAX (MPFR_EXP_INVALID-1)
902
903/* Use MPFR_GET_EXP and MPFR_SET_EXP instead of MPFR_EXP directly,
904 unless when the exponent may be out-of-range, for instance when
905 setting the exponent before calling mpfr_check_range.
906 MPFR_EXP_CHECK is defined when MPFR_WANT_ASSERT is defined, but if you
907 don't use MPFR_WANT_ASSERT (for speed reasons), you can still define
908 MPFR_EXP_CHECK by setting -DMPFR_EXP_CHECK in $CFLAGS.
909 Note about MPFR_EXP_IN_RANGE and MPFR_SET_EXP:
910 The exp expression is required to have a signed type. To avoid spurious
911 failures, we could cast (exp) to mpfr_exp_t, but this wouldn't allow us
912 to detect some bugs that can occur on particular platforms. Anyway, an
913 unsigned type for exp is suspicious and should be regarded as a bug.
914*/
915
916#define MPFR_EXP_IN_RANGE(e) \
917 (MPFR_ASSERTD (IS_SIGNED (e)), (e) >= __gmpfr_emin && (e) <= __gmpfr_emax)
918
919#ifdef MPFR_EXP_CHECK
920# define MPFR_GET_EXP(x) (mpfr_get_exp) (x)
921# define MPFR_SET_EXP(x,e) (MPFR_ASSERTN (MPFR_EXP_IN_RANGE (e)), \
922 (void) (MPFR_EXP (x) = (e)))
923# define MPFR_SET_INVALID_EXP(x) ((void) (MPFR_EXP (x) = MPFR_EXP_INVALID))
924#else
925# define MPFR_GET_EXP(x) MPFR_EXP (x)
926# define MPFR_SET_EXP(x,e) ((void) (MPFR_EXP (x) = (e)))
927# define MPFR_SET_INVALID_EXP(x) ((void) 0)
928#endif
929
930#define MPFR_UBF_EXP_LESS_P(x,y) \
931 (MPFR_UNLIKELY (MPFR_IS_UBF (x) || MPFR_IS_UBF (y)) ? \
932 mpfr_ubf_exp_less_p (x, y) : MPFR_GET_EXP (x) < MPFR_GET_EXP (y))
933
934
935/******************************************************
936 ********* Singular values (NAN, INF, ZERO) *********
937 ******************************************************/
938
939/* Enum special value of exponent. */
940# define MPFR_EXP_ZERO (MPFR_EXP_MIN+1)
941# define MPFR_EXP_NAN (MPFR_EXP_MIN+2)
942# define MPFR_EXP_INF (MPFR_EXP_MIN+3)
943# define MPFR_EXP_UBF (MPFR_EXP_MIN+4)
944
945#define MPFR_IS_NAN(x) (MPFR_EXP(x) == MPFR_EXP_NAN)
946#define MPFR_SET_NAN(x) (MPFR_EXP(x) = MPFR_EXP_NAN)
947#define MPFR_IS_INF(x) (MPFR_EXP(x) == MPFR_EXP_INF)
948#define MPFR_SET_INF(x) (MPFR_EXP(x) = MPFR_EXP_INF)
949#define MPFR_IS_ZERO(x) (MPFR_EXP(x) == MPFR_EXP_ZERO)
950#define MPFR_SET_ZERO(x) (MPFR_EXP(x) = MPFR_EXP_ZERO)
951#define MPFR_NOTZERO(x) (MPFR_EXP(x) != MPFR_EXP_ZERO)
952#define MPFR_IS_UBF(x) (MPFR_EXP(x) == MPFR_EXP_UBF)
953#define MPFR_SET_UBF(x) (MPFR_EXP(x) = MPFR_EXP_UBF)
954
955#define MPFR_IS_NORMALIZED(x) \
956 (MPFR_LIMB_MSB (MPFR_MANT(x)[MPFR_LAST_LIMB(x)]) != 0)
957
958#define MPFR_IS_FP(x) (!MPFR_IS_NAN(x) && !MPFR_IS_INF(x))
959/* Note: contrary to the MPFR_IS_PURE_*(x) macros, the MPFR_IS_SINGULAR*(x)
960 macros may be used even when x is being constructed, i.e. its exponent
961 field is already set (possibly out-of-range), but its significand field
962 may still contain arbitrary data. Thus MPFR_IS_PURE_FP(x) is not always
963 equivalent to !MPFR_IS_SINGULAR(x); see the code below. */
964#define MPFR_IS_SINGULAR(x) (MPFR_EXP(x) <= MPFR_EXP_INF)
965#define MPFR_IS_SINGULAR_OR_UBF(x) (MPFR_EXP(x) <= MPFR_EXP_UBF)
966#define MPFR_IS_PURE_FP(x) \
967 (!MPFR_IS_SINGULAR(x) && \
968 (MPFR_ASSERTD (MPFR_EXP (x) >= MPFR_EMIN_MIN && \
969 MPFR_EXP (x) <= MPFR_EMAX_MAX && \
970 MPFR_IS_NORMALIZED (x)), 1))
971#define MPFR_IS_PURE_UBF(x) \
972 (!MPFR_IS_SINGULAR(x) && \
973 (MPFR_ASSERTD ((MPFR_IS_UBF (x) || \
974 (MPFR_EXP (x) >= MPFR_EMIN_MIN && \
975 MPFR_EXP (x) <= MPFR_EMAX_MAX)) && \
976 MPFR_IS_NORMALIZED (x)), 1))
977
978#define MPFR_ARE_SINGULAR(x,y) \
979 (MPFR_UNLIKELY(MPFR_IS_SINGULAR(x)) || MPFR_UNLIKELY(MPFR_IS_SINGULAR(y)))
980
981#define MPFR_ARE_SINGULAR_OR_UBF(x,y) \
982 (MPFR_UNLIKELY(MPFR_IS_SINGULAR_OR_UBF(x)) || \
983 MPFR_UNLIKELY(MPFR_IS_SINGULAR_OR_UBF(y)))
984
985
986/******************************************************
987 ******************** Sign macros *******************
988 ******************************************************/
989
990/* These are sign macros for MPFR numbers only. */
991
992#define MPFR_SIGN_POS (1)
993#define MPFR_SIGN_NEG (-1)
994
995#define MPFR_IS_STRICTPOS(x) (MPFR_NOTZERO (x) && MPFR_IS_POS (x))
996#define MPFR_IS_STRICTNEG(x) (MPFR_NOTZERO (x) && MPFR_IS_NEG (x))
997
998#define MPFR_IS_NEG(x) (MPFR_SIGN(x) < 0)
999#define MPFR_IS_POS(x) (MPFR_SIGN(x) > 0)
1000
1001#define MPFR_SET_POS(x) (MPFR_SIGN(x) = MPFR_SIGN_POS)
1002#define MPFR_SET_NEG(x) (MPFR_SIGN(x) = MPFR_SIGN_NEG)
1003
1004#define MPFR_CHANGE_SIGN(x) (MPFR_SIGN(x) = -MPFR_SIGN(x))
1005#define MPFR_SET_SAME_SIGN(x, y) (MPFR_SIGN(x) = MPFR_SIGN(y))
1006#define MPFR_SET_OPPOSITE_SIGN(x, y) (MPFR_SIGN(x) = -MPFR_SIGN(y))
1007#define MPFR_ASSERT_SIGN(s) \
1008 (MPFR_ASSERTD((s) == MPFR_SIGN_POS || (s) == MPFR_SIGN_NEG))
1009#define MPFR_SET_SIGN(x, s) \
1010 (MPFR_ASSERT_SIGN(s), MPFR_SIGN(x) = s)
1011#define MPFR_IS_POS_SIGN(s1) ((s1) > 0)
1012#define MPFR_IS_NEG_SIGN(s1) ((s1) < 0)
1013#define MPFR_MULT_SIGN(s1, s2) ((s1) * (s2))
1014/* Transform a sign to 1 or -1 */
1015#define MPFR_FROM_SIGN_TO_INT(s) (s)
1016#define MPFR_INT_SIGN(x) MPFR_FROM_SIGN_TO_INT(MPFR_SIGN(x))
1017
1018
1019/******************************************************
1020 *************** Ternary value macros ***************
1021 ******************************************************/
1022
1023/* Special inexact value */
1024#define MPFR_EVEN_INEX 2
1025
1026/* Macros for functions returning two inexact values in an 'int' */
1027#define INEXPOS(y) ((y) == 0 ? 0 : (((y) > 0) ? 1 : 2))
1028#define INEX(y,z) (INEXPOS(y) | (INEXPOS(z) << 2))
1029
1030/* When returning the ternary inexact value, ALWAYS use one of the
1031 following two macros, unless the flag comes from another function
1032 returning the ternary inexact value */
1033#define MPFR_RET(I) return \
1034 (I) != 0 ? ((__gmpfr_flags |= MPFR_FLAGS_INEXACT), (I)) : 0
1035#define MPFR_RET_NAN return (__gmpfr_flags |= MPFR_FLAGS_NAN), 0
1036
1037/* Sign of a native value. */
1038#define VSIGN(I) ((I) < 0 ? -1 : (I) > 0)
1039#define SAME_SIGN(I1,I2) (VSIGN (I1) == VSIGN (I2))
1040
1041
1042/******************************************************
1043 *************** Rounding mode macros ***************
1044 ******************************************************/
1045
1046/* MPFR_RND_MAX gives the number of supported rounding modes by all functions.
1047 */
1048#define MPFR_RND_MAX ((mpfr_rnd_t)((MPFR_RNDF)+1))
1049
1050/* We want to test this :
1051 * (rnd == MPFR_RNDU && test) || (rnd == RNDD && !test)
1052 * ie it transforms RNDU or RNDD to Away or Zero according to the sign */
1053#define MPFR_IS_RNDUTEST_OR_RNDDNOTTEST(rnd, test) \
1054 (((rnd) + (test)) == MPFR_RNDD)
1055
1056/* We want to test if rnd = Zero, or Away.
1057 'neg' is 1 if negative, and 0 if positive. */
1058#define MPFR_IS_LIKE_RNDZ(rnd, neg) \
1059 ((rnd) == MPFR_RNDZ || MPFR_IS_RNDUTEST_OR_RNDDNOTTEST (rnd, neg))
1060
1061#define MPFR_IS_LIKE_RNDA(rnd, neg) \
1062 ((rnd) == MPFR_RNDA || MPFR_IS_RNDUTEST_OR_RNDDNOTTEST (rnd, (neg) == 0))
1063
1064#define MPFR_IS_LIKE_RNDU(rnd, sign) \
1065 (((rnd) == MPFR_RNDU) || \
1066 ((rnd) == MPFR_RNDZ && MPFR_IS_NEG_SIGN (sign)) || \
1067 ((rnd) == MPFR_RNDA && MPFR_IS_POS_SIGN (sign)))
1068
1069#define MPFR_IS_LIKE_RNDD(rnd, sign) \
1070 (((rnd) == MPFR_RNDD) || \
1071 ((rnd) == MPFR_RNDZ && MPFR_IS_POS_SIGN (sign)) || \
1072 ((rnd) == MPFR_RNDA && MPFR_IS_NEG_SIGN (sign)))
1073
1074/* Invert a rounding mode, RNDN, RNDZ and RNDA are unchanged */
1075#define MPFR_INVERT_RND(rnd) ((rnd) == MPFR_RNDU ? MPFR_RNDD : \
1076 (rnd) == MPFR_RNDD ? MPFR_RNDU : (rnd))
1077
1078/* Transform RNDU and RNDD to RNDZ according to test */
1079#define MPFR_UPDATE_RND_MODE(rnd, test) \
1080 do { \
1081 if (MPFR_UNLIKELY(MPFR_IS_RNDUTEST_OR_RNDDNOTTEST(rnd, test))) \
1082 rnd = MPFR_RNDZ; \
1083 } while (0)
1084
1085/* Transform RNDU and RNDD to RNDZ or RNDA according to sign,
1086 leave the other modes unchanged */
1087#define MPFR_UPDATE2_RND_MODE(rnd, sign) \
1088 do { \
1089 if (rnd == MPFR_RNDU) \
1090 rnd = MPFR_IS_POS_SIGN (sign) ? MPFR_RNDA : MPFR_RNDZ; \
1091 else if (rnd == MPFR_RNDD) \
1092 rnd = MPFR_IS_NEG_SIGN (sign) ? MPFR_RNDA : MPFR_RNDZ; \
1093 } while (0)
1094
1095
1096/******************************************************
1097 ****************** Limb macros *********************
1098 ******************************************************/
1099
1100/* Definition of simple mp_limb_t constants */
1101#define MPFR_LIMB_ZERO ((mp_limb_t) 0)
1102#define MPFR_LIMB_ONE ((mp_limb_t) 1)
1103#define MPFR_LIMB_HIGHBIT (MPFR_LIMB_ONE << (GMP_NUMB_BITS - 1))
1104#define MPFR_LIMB_MAX ((mp_limb_t) -1)
1105
1106/* Mask to get the Most Significant Bit of a limb */
1107#define MPFR_LIMB_MSB(l) ((l) & MPFR_LIMB_HIGHBIT)
1108
1109/* Mask for the low 's' bits of a limb */
1110#define MPFR_LIMB_MASK(s) ((MPFR_LIMB_ONE << (s)) - MPFR_LIMB_ONE)
1111
1112
1113/******************************************************
1114 ********************** Memory **********************
1115 ******************************************************/
1116
1117#define MPFR_BYTES_PER_MP_LIMB (GMP_NUMB_BITS/CHAR_BIT)
1118
1119/* Heap memory handling
1120 --------------------
1121 Memory allocated for a significand (mantissa) has the following
1122 format:
1123 * A mp_size_t in a mpfr_size_limb_t union (see below).
1124 * An array of mp_limb_t (not all of them are necessarily used,
1125 as the precision can change without a reallocation).
1126 The goal of the mpfr_size_limb_t union is to make sure that
1127 size and alignment requirements are satisfied if mp_size_t and
1128 mp_limb_t have different sizes and/or alignment requirements.
1129 Moreover, pointer conversions are not fully specified by the
1130 C standard, and the use of a union (and the double casts below)
1131 might help even if mp_size_t and mp_limb_t have the same size
1132 and the same alignment requirements. Still, there is currently
1133 no guarantee that this code is portable. Note that union members
1134 are not used at all.
1135*/
1136typedef union { mp_size_t s; mp_limb_t l; } mpfr_size_limb_t;
1137#define MPFR_GET_ALLOC_SIZE(x) \
1138 (((mp_size_t *) (mpfr_size_limb_t *) MPFR_MANT(x))[-1] + 0)
1139#define MPFR_SET_ALLOC_SIZE(x, n) \
1140 (((mp_size_t *) (mpfr_size_limb_t *) MPFR_MANT(x))[-1] = (n))
1141#define MPFR_MALLOC_SIZE(s) \
1142 (sizeof(mpfr_size_limb_t) + MPFR_BYTES_PER_MP_LIMB * (size_t) (s))
1143#define MPFR_SET_MANT_PTR(x,p) \
1144 (MPFR_MANT(x) = (mp_limb_t *) ((mpfr_size_limb_t *) (p) + 1))
1145#define MPFR_GET_REAL_PTR(x) \
1146 ((mp_limb_t *) ((mpfr_size_limb_t *) MPFR_MANT(x) - 1))
1147
1148/* Temporary memory handling */
1149#ifndef TMP_SALLOC
1150/* GMP 4.1.x or below or internals */
1151#define MPFR_TMP_DECL TMP_DECL
1152#define MPFR_TMP_MARK TMP_MARK
1153#define MPFR_TMP_ALLOC TMP_ALLOC
1154#define MPFR_TMP_FREE TMP_FREE
1155#else
1156#define MPFR_TMP_DECL(x) TMP_DECL
1157#define MPFR_TMP_MARK(x) TMP_MARK
1158#define MPFR_TMP_ALLOC(s) TMP_ALLOC(s)
1159#define MPFR_TMP_FREE(x) TMP_FREE
1160#endif
1161
1162#define MPFR_TMP_LIMBS_ALLOC(N) \
1163 ((mp_limb_t *) MPFR_TMP_ALLOC ((size_t) (N) * MPFR_BYTES_PER_MP_LIMB))
1164
1165/* temporary allocate 1 limb at xp, and initialize mpfr variable x */
1166/* The temporary var doesn't have any size field, but it doesn't matter
1167 * since only functions dealing with the Heap care about it */
1168#define MPFR_TMP_INIT1(xp, x, p) \
1169 ( MPFR_PREC(x) = (p), \
1170 MPFR_MANT(x) = (xp), \
1171 MPFR_SET_POS(x), \
1172 MPFR_SET_INVALID_EXP(x))
1173
1174#define MPFR_TMP_INIT(xp, x, p, s) \
1175 (xp = MPFR_TMP_LIMBS_ALLOC(s), \
1176 MPFR_TMP_INIT1(xp, x, p))
1177
1178#define MPFR_TMP_INIT_ABS(d, s) \
1179 ( MPFR_PREC(d) = MPFR_PREC(s), \
1180 MPFR_MANT(d) = MPFR_MANT(s), \
1181 MPFR_SET_POS(d), \
1182 MPFR_EXP(d) = MPFR_EXP(s))
1183
1184#define MPFR_TMP_INIT_NEG(d, s) \
1185 ( MPFR_PREC(d) = MPFR_PREC(s), \
1186 MPFR_MANT(d) = MPFR_MANT(s), \
1187 MPFR_SET_OPPOSITE_SIGN(d,s), \
1188 MPFR_EXP(d) = MPFR_EXP(s))
1189
1190
1191/******************************************************
1192 ******************* Cache macros *******************
1193 ******************************************************/
1194
1195/* Cache struct */
1196#define mpfr_const_pi(_d,_r) mpfr_cache(_d, __gmpfr_cache_const_pi,_r)
1197#define mpfr_const_log2(_d,_r) mpfr_cache(_d, __gmpfr_cache_const_log2, _r)
1198#define mpfr_const_euler(_d,_r) mpfr_cache(_d, __gmpfr_cache_const_euler, _r)
1199#define mpfr_const_catalan(_d,_r) mpfr_cache(_d,__gmpfr_cache_const_catalan,_r)
1200
1201/* Declare a global cache for a MPFR constant.
1202 If the shared cache is enabled, and if the constructor/destructor
1203 attributes are available, we need to initialize the shared lock of
1204 the cache with a constructor. It is the goal of the macro
1205 MPFR_DEFERRED_INIT_MASTER_DECL.
1206 FIXME: When MPFR is built with shared cache, the field "lock" is
1207 not explicitly initialized, which can yield a warning, e.g. with
1208 GCC's -Wmissing-field-initializers (and an error with -Werror).
1209 Since one does not know what is behind the associated typedef name,
1210 one cannot provide an explicit initialization for such a type. Two
1211 possible solutions:
1212 1. Encapsulate the type in a structure or a union and use the
1213 universal zero initializer: { 0 }
1214 But: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=80454
1215 2. Use designated initializers when supported. But this needs a
1216 configure test.
1217*/
1218#define MPFR_DECL_INIT_CACHE(_cache,_func) \
1219 MPFR_DEFERRED_INIT_MASTER_DECL(_func, \
1220 MPFR_LOCK_INIT( (_cache)->lock), \
1221 MPFR_LOCK_CLEAR((_cache)->lock)) \
1222 MPFR_CACHE_ATTR mpfr_cache_t _cache = {{ \
1223 {{ 0, MPFR_SIGN_POS, 0, (mp_limb_t *) 0 }}, 0, _func \
1224 MPFR_DEFERRED_INIT_SLAVE_VALUE(_func) \
1225 }}; \
1226 MPFR_MAKE_VARFCT (mpfr_cache_t,_cache)
1227

1232#include "mparam.h"

1235/******************************************************
1236 ****************** Useful macros *******************
1237 ******************************************************/
1238
1239/* Theses macros help the compiler to determine if a test is
1240 likely or unlikely. The !! is necessary in case x is larger
1241 than a long. */
1242#if defined MPFR_DEBUG_PREDICTION && __MPFR_GNUC(3,0)
1243
1244/* Code to debug branch prediction, based on Ulrich Drepper's paper
1245 * "What Every Programmer Should Know About Memory":
1246 * http://people.freebsd.org/~lstewart/articles/cpumemory.pdf
1247 */
1248asm (".section predict_data, \"aw\"; .previous\n"
1249 ".section predict_line, \"a\"; .previous\n"
1250 ".section predict_file, \"a\"; .previous");
1251# if defined __x86_64__
1252# define MPFR_DEBUGPRED__(e,E) \
1253 ({ long _e = !!(e); \
1254 asm volatile (".pushsection predict_data\n" \
1255 "..predictcnt%=: .quad 0; .quad 0\n" \
1256 ".section predict_line; .quad %c1\n" \
1257 ".section predict_file; .quad %c2; .popsection\n" \
1258 "addq $1,..predictcnt%=(,%0,8)" \
1259 : : "r" (_e == E), "i" (__LINE__), "i" (__FILE__)); \
1260 __builtin_expect (_e, E); \
1261 })
1262# elif defined __i386__
1263# define MPFR_DEBUGPRED__(e,E) \
1264 ({ long _e = !!(e); \
1265 asm volatile (".pushsection predict_data\n" \
1266 "..predictcnt%=: .long 0; .long 0\n" \
1267 ".section predict_line; .long %c1\n" \
1268 ".section predict_file; .long %c2; .popsection\n" \
1269 "incl ..predictcnt%=(,%0,4)" \
1270 : : "r" (_e == E), "i" (__LINE__), "i" (__FILE__)); \
1271 __builtin_expect (_e, E); \
1272 })
1273# else
1274# error "MPFR_DEBUGPRED__ definition missing"
1275# endif
1276
1277# define MPFR_LIKELY(x) MPFR_DEBUGPRED__ ((x), 1)
1278# define MPFR_UNLIKELY(x) MPFR_DEBUGPRED__ ((x), 0)
1279
1280#elif __MPFR_GNUC(3,0) || __MPFR_ICC(8,1,0)
1281
1282# define MPFR_LIKELY(x) (__builtin_expect(!!(x), 1))
1283# define MPFR_UNLIKELY(x) (__builtin_expect(!!(x), 0))
1284
1285#else
1286
1287# define MPFR_LIKELY(x) (x)
1288# define MPFR_UNLIKELY(x) (x)
1289
1290#endif
1291
1292/* Declare that some variable is initialized before being used (without a
1293 dummy initialization) in order to avoid some compiler warnings. Use the
1294 VAR = VAR trick (see https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=36296#c3)
1295 only with gcc as this is undefined behavior, and we don't know what other
1296 compilers do (they may also be smarter). This self-initialization trick
1297 could be disabled with future gcc versions.
1298 However, for clang (which defines __GNUC__), this trick must not be used
1299 as it currently generates a warning, at least with:
1300 Debian clang version 3.0-6.2 (tags/RELEASE_30/final) (based on LLVM 3.0)
1301 __VERSION__ "4.2.1 Compatible Debian Clang 3.0 (tags/RELEASE_30/final)"
1302 __clang__ 1
1303 __clang_major__ 3
1304 __clang_minor__ 0
1305 __clang_patchlevel__ 0
1306 __clang_version__ "3.0 (tags/RELEASE_30/final)"
1307 (see https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=705583 for this
1308 problem with clang). */
1309#if defined(__GNUC__) && !defined(__clang__)
1310# define INITIALIZED(VAR) VAR = VAR
1311#else
1312# define INITIALIZED(VAR) VAR
1313#endif
1314
1315/* Ceil log 2: If GCC, uses a GCC extension, otherwise calls a function */
1316/* Warning:
1317 * Needs to define MPFR_NEED_LONGLONG.
1318 * Computes ceil(log2(x)) only for x integer (unsigned long)
1319 * Undefined if x is 0 */
1320#if __MPFR_GNUC(2,95) || __MPFR_ICC(8,1,0)
1321/* Note: This macro MPFR_INT_CEIL_LOG2 shouldn't be used in an MPFR_ASSERT*
1322 macro, either directly or indirectly via other macros, otherwise it can
1323 yield an error due to a too large stringized expression in ASSERT_FAIL.
1324 A static inline function could be a better solution than this macro. */
1325/* FIXME: The current code assumes that x fits in an unsigned long
1326 (used by __gmpfr_int_ceil_log2) while MPFR_INT_CEIL_LOG2 is used on
1327 values that might be larger than ULONG_MAX on some platforms and/or
1328 with some build options; a loop could be used if x > ULONG_MAX. If
1329 the type of x is <= unsigned long, then no additional code will be
1330 generated thanks to obvious compiler optimization. */
1331# define MPFR_INT_CEIL_LOG2(x) \
1332 (MPFR_UNLIKELY ((x) == 1) ? 0 : \
1333 __extension__ ({ int _b; mp_limb_t _limb; \
1334 MPFR_ASSERTN ((x) > 1); \
1335 _limb = (x) - 1; \
1336 MPFR_ASSERTN (_limb == (x) - 1); \
1337 count_leading_zeros (_b, _limb); \
1338 (GMP_NUMB_BITS - _b); }))
1339#else
1340# define MPFR_INT_CEIL_LOG2(x) \
1341 (MPFR_ASSERTN (x <= ULONG_MAX), __gmpfr_int_ceil_log2(x))
1342#endif
1343
1344/* Add two integers with overflow handling */
1345/* Example: MPFR_SADD_OVERFLOW (c, a, b, long, unsigned long,
1346 * LONG_MIN, LONG_MAX,
1347 * goto overflow, goto underflow); */
1348#define MPFR_UADD_OVERFLOW(c,a,b,ACTION_IF_OVERFLOW) \
1349 do { \
1350 (c) = (a) + (b); \
1351 if ((c) < (a)) ACTION_IF_OVERFLOW; \
1352 } while (0)
1353
1354#define MPFR_SADD_OVERFLOW(c,a,b,STYPE,UTYPE,MIN,MAX,ACTION_IF_POS_OVERFLOW,ACTION_IF_NEG_OVERFLOW) \
1355 do { \
1356 if ((a) >= 0 && (b) >= 0) { \
1357 UTYPE uc,ua,ub; \
1358 ua = (UTYPE) (a); ub = (UTYPE) (b); \
1359 MPFR_UADD_OVERFLOW (uc, ua, ub, ACTION_IF_POS_OVERFLOW); \
1360 if (uc > (UTYPE)(MAX)) ACTION_IF_POS_OVERFLOW; \
1361 else (c) = (STYPE) uc; \
1362 } else if ((a) < 0 && (b) < 0) { \
1363 UTYPE uc,ua,ub; \
1364 ua = -(UTYPE) (a); ub = -(UTYPE) (b); \
1365 MPFR_UADD_OVERFLOW (uc, ua, ub, ACTION_IF_NEG_OVERFLOW); \
1366 if (uc >= -(UTYPE)(MIN) || uc > (UTYPE)(MAX)) { \
1367 if (uc == -(UTYPE)(MIN)) (c) = (MIN); \
1368 else ACTION_IF_NEG_OVERFLOW; } \
1369 else (c) = -(STYPE) uc; \
1370 } else (c) = (a) + (b); \
1371 } while (0)
1372
1373
1374/* Set a number to 1 (Fast) - It doesn't check if 1 is in the exponent range */
1375#define MPFR_SET_ONE(x) \
1376do { \
1377 mp_size_t _size = MPFR_LAST_LIMB(x); \
1378 MPFR_SET_POS(x); \
1379 MPFR_EXP(x) = 1; \
1380 MPN_ZERO ( MPFR_MANT(x), _size); \
1381 MPFR_MANT(x)[_size] = MPFR_LIMB_HIGHBIT; \
1382} while (0)
1383
1384/* Compute s = (-a) % GMP_NUMB_BITS as unsigned */
1385#define MPFR_UNSIGNED_MINUS_MODULO(s, a) \
1386 do \
1387 { \
1388 if (IS_POW2 (GMP_NUMB_BITS)) \
1389 (s) = (- (unsigned int) (a)) % GMP_NUMB_BITS; \
1390 else \
1391 { \
1392 (s) = (a) % GMP_NUMB_BITS; \
1393 if ((s) != 0) \
1394 (s) = GMP_NUMB_BITS - (s); \
1395 } \
1396 MPFR_ASSERTD ((s) >= 0 && (s) < GMP_NUMB_BITS); \
1397 } \
1398 while (0)
1399
1400/* Test if X (positive) is a power of 2 */
1401#define IS_POW2(X) (((X) & ((X) - 1)) == 0)
1402#define NOT_POW2(X) (((X) & ((X) - 1)) != 0)
1403
1404/* Safe absolute value and difference (to avoid possible integer overflow) */
1405/* type is the target (unsigned) type */
1406#define SAFE_ABS(type,x) ((x) >= 0 ? (type)(x) : -(type)(x))
1407#define SAFE_DIFF(type,x,y) (MPFR_ASSERTD((x) >= (y)), (type)(x) - (type)(y))
1408
1409/* Check whether an integer type (after integer promotion) is signed.
1410 This can be determined at compilation time, but unfortunately this
1411 is not a constant expression, so that this cannot be used for a
1412 static assertion. */
1413#define IS_SIGNED(X) ((X) * 0 - 1 < 0)
1414
1415#define mpfr_get_d1(x) mpfr_get_d(x,__gmpfr_default_rounding_mode)
1416
1417/* Store in r the size in bits of the mpz_t z */
1418#define MPFR_MPZ_SIZEINBASE2(r, z) \
1419 do { \
1420 int _cnt; \
1421 mp_size_t _size; \
1422 MPFR_ASSERTD (mpz_sgn (z) != 0); \
1423 _size = ABSIZ(z); \
1424 MPFR_ASSERTD (_size >= 1); \
1425 count_leading_zeros (_cnt, PTR(z)[_size-1]); \
1426 (r) = _size * GMP_NUMB_BITS - _cnt; \
1427 } while (0)
1428
1429/* MPFR_LCONV_DPTS can also be forced to 0 or 1 by the user. */
1430#ifndef MPFR_LCONV_DPTS
1431# if defined(HAVE_LOCALE_H) && \
1432 defined(HAVE_STRUCT_LCONV_DECIMAL_POINT) && \
1433 defined(HAVE_STRUCT_LCONV_THOUSANDS_SEP)
1434# define MPFR_LCONV_DPTS 1
1435# else
1436# define MPFR_LCONV_DPTS 0
1437# endif
1438#endif
1439
1440/* FIXME: Add support for multibyte decimal_point and thousands_sep since
1441 this can be found in practice: https://reviews.llvm.org/D27167 says:
1442 "I found this problem on FreeBSD 11, where thousands_sep in fr_FR.UTF-8
1443 is a no-break space (U+00A0)."
1444 Note, however, that this is not allowed by the C standard, which just
1445 says "character" and not "multibyte character".
1446 In the mean time, in case of non-single-byte character, revert to the
1447 default value. */
1448#if MPFR_LCONV_DPTS
1449#include <locale.h>
1450/* Warning! In case of signed char, the value of MPFR_DECIMAL_POINT may
1451 be negative (the ISO C99 does not seem to forbid negative values). */
1452#define MPFR_DECIMAL_POINT \
1453 (localeconv()->decimal_point[1] != '\0' ? \
1454 (char) '.' : localeconv()->decimal_point[0])
1455#define MPFR_THOUSANDS_SEPARATOR \
1456 (localeconv()->thousands_sep[0] == '\0' || \
1457 localeconv()->thousands_sep[1] != '\0' ? \
1458 (char) '\0' : localeconv()->thousands_sep[0])
1459#else
1460#define MPFR_DECIMAL_POINT ((char) '.')
1461#define MPFR_THOUSANDS_SEPARATOR ((char) '\0')
1462#endif
1463
1464
1465/* Set y to s*significand(x)*2^e, for example MPFR_ALIAS(y,x,1,MPFR_EXP(x))
1466 sets y to |x|, and MPFR_ALIAS(y,x,MPFR_SIGN(x),0) sets y to x*2^f such
1467 that 1/2 <= |y| < 1. Does not check y is in the valid exponent range.
1468 WARNING! x and y share the same mantissa. So, some operations are
1469 not valid if x has been provided via an argument, e.g., trying to
1470 modify the mantissa of y, even temporarily, or calling mpfr_clear on y.
1471*/
1472#define MPFR_ALIAS(y,x,s,e) \
1473 do \
1474 { \
1475 MPFR_PREC(y) = MPFR_PREC(x); \
1476 MPFR_SIGN(y) = (s); \
1477 MPFR_EXP(y) = (e); \
1478 MPFR_MANT(y) = MPFR_MANT(x); \
1479 } while (0)
1480
1481/* Size of an array, as a constant expression. */
1482#define numberof_const(x) (sizeof (x) / sizeof ((x)[0]))
1483
1484/* Addition with carry (detected by GCC and other good compilers). */
1485#define ADD_LIMB(u,v,c) ((u) += (v), (c) = (u) < (v))
1486

1488/******************************************************
1489 ************ Save exponent/flags macros ************
1490 ******************************************************/
1491
1492/* See README.dev for details on how to use the macros.
1493 They are used to set the exponent range to the maximum
1494 temporarily */
1495
1496typedef struct {
1497 mpfr_flags_t saved_flags;
1498 mpfr_exp_t saved_emin;
1499 mpfr_exp_t saved_emax;
1500} mpfr_save_expo_t;
1501
1502/* Minimum and maximum exponents of the extended exponent range. */
1503#define MPFR_EXT_EMIN MPFR_EMIN_MIN
1504#define MPFR_EXT_EMAX MPFR_EMAX_MAX
1505
1506#define MPFR_SAVE_EXPO_DECL(x) mpfr_save_expo_t x
1507#define MPFR_SAVE_EXPO_MARK(x) \
1508 ((x).saved_flags = __gmpfr_flags, \
1509 (x).saved_emin = __gmpfr_emin, \
1510 (x).saved_emax = __gmpfr_emax, \
1511 __gmpfr_emin = MPFR_EXT_EMIN, \
1512 __gmpfr_emax = MPFR_EXT_EMAX)
1513#define MPFR_SAVE_EXPO_FREE(x) \
1514 (__gmpfr_flags = (x).saved_flags, \
1515 __gmpfr_emin = (x).saved_emin, \
1516 __gmpfr_emax = (x).saved_emax)
1517#define MPFR_SAVE_EXPO_UPDATE_FLAGS(x, flags) \
1518 (x).saved_flags |= (flags)
1519
1520/* Speed up final checking */
1521#define mpfr_check_range(x,t,r) \
1522 (MPFR_LIKELY (MPFR_EXP_IN_RANGE (MPFR_EXP (x))) \
1523 ? ((t) ? (__gmpfr_flags |= MPFR_FLAGS_INEXACT, (t)) : 0) \
1524 : mpfr_check_range(x,t,r))

1527/******************************************************
1528 ***************** Inline rounding ******************
1529 ******************************************************/
1530
1531/*
1532 * Note: due to the labels, one cannot use a macro MPFR_RNDRAW* more than
1533 * once in a function (otherwise these labels would not be unique).
1534 */
1535
1536/*
1537 * Round mantissa (srcp, sprec) to mpfr_t dest using rounding mode rnd
1538 * assuming dest's sign is sign.
1539 * In rounding to nearest mode, execute MIDDLE_HANDLER when the value
1540 * is the middle of two consecutive numbers in dest precision.
1541 * Execute OVERFLOW_HANDLER in case of overflow when rounding.
1542 *
1543 * Note: the exponent field of dest is not used, possibly except by the
1544 * handlers. It is the caller (via the handlers) who entirely decides
1545 * how to handle it.
1546 */
1547#define MPFR_RNDRAW_GEN(inexact, dest, srcp, sprec, rnd, sign, \
1548 MIDDLE_HANDLER, OVERFLOW_HANDLER) \
1549 do { \
1550 mp_size_t _dests, _srcs; \
1551 mp_limb_t *_destp; \
1552 mpfr_prec_t _destprec, _srcprec; \
1553 \
1554 /* Check Trivial Case when Dest Mantissa has more bits than source */ \
1555 _srcprec = (sprec); \
1556 _destprec = MPFR_PREC (dest); \
1557 MPFR_ASSERTD (_srcprec >= MPFR_PREC_MIN); \
1558 MPFR_ASSERTD (_destprec >= MPFR_PREC_MIN); \
1559 _destp = MPFR_MANT (dest); \
1560 if (MPFR_UNLIKELY (_destprec >= _srcprec)) \
1561 { \
1562 _srcs = MPFR_PREC2LIMBS (_srcprec); \
1563 _dests = MPFR_PREC2LIMBS (_destprec) - _srcs; \
1564 MPN_COPY (_destp + _dests, srcp, _srcs); \
1565 MPN_ZERO (_destp, _dests); \
1566 inexact = 0; \
1567 } \
1568 else \
1569 { \
1570 /* Non trivial case: rounding needed */ \
1571 mpfr_prec_t _sh; \
1572 mp_limb_t *_sp; \
1573 mp_limb_t _rb, _sb, _ulp; \
1574 \
1575 /* Compute Position and shift */ \
1576 _srcs = MPFR_PREC2LIMBS (_srcprec); \
1577 _dests = MPFR_PREC2LIMBS (_destprec); \
1578 MPFR_UNSIGNED_MINUS_MODULO (_sh, _destprec); \
1579 _sp = (srcp) + _srcs - _dests; \
1580 \
1581 /* General case when prec % GMP_NUMB_BITS != 0 */ \
1582 if (MPFR_LIKELY (_sh != 0)) \
1583 { \
1584 mp_limb_t _mask; \
1585 /* Compute Rounding Bit and Sticky Bit */ \
1586 /* Note: in directed rounding modes, if the rounding bit */ \
1587 /* is 1, the behavior does not depend on the sticky bit; */ \
1588 /* thus we will not try to compute it in this case (this */ \
1589 /* can be much faster and avoids to read uninitialized */ \
1590 /* data in the current mpfr_mul implementation). We just */ \
1591 /* make sure that _sb is initialized. */ \
1592 _mask = MPFR_LIMB_ONE << (_sh - 1); \
1593 _rb = _sp[0] & _mask; \
1594 _sb = _sp[0] & (_mask - 1); \
1595 if ((rnd) == MPFR_RNDN || _rb == 0) \
1596 { \
1597 mp_limb_t *_tmp; \
1598 mp_size_t _n; \
1599 for (_tmp = _sp, _n = _srcs - _dests ; \
1600 _n != 0 && _sb == 0 ; _n--) \
1601 _sb = *--_tmp; \
1602 } \
1603 _ulp = 2 * _mask; \
1604 } \
1605 else /* _sh == 0 */ \
1606 { \
1607 MPFR_ASSERTD (_dests < _srcs); \
1608 /* Compute Rounding Bit and Sticky Bit - see note above */ \
1609 _rb = _sp[-1] & MPFR_LIMB_HIGHBIT; \
1610 _sb = _sp[-1] & (MPFR_LIMB_HIGHBIT-1); \
1611 if ((rnd) == MPFR_RNDN || _rb == 0) \
1612 { \
1613 mp_limb_t *_tmp; \
1614 mp_size_t _n; \
1615 for (_tmp = _sp - 1, _n = _srcs - _dests - 1 ; \
1616 _n != 0 && _sb == 0 ; _n--) \
1617 _sb = *--_tmp; \
1618 } \
1619 _ulp = MPFR_LIMB_ONE; \
1620 } \
1621 /* Rounding */ \
1622 if (rnd == MPFR_RNDF) \
1623 { \
1624 inexact = 0; \
1625 goto trunc_doit; \
1626 } \
1627 else if (rnd == MPFR_RNDN) \
1628 { \
1629 if (_rb == 0) \
1630 { \
1631 trunc: \
1632 inexact = MPFR_LIKELY ((_sb | _rb) != 0) ? -sign : 0; \
1633 trunc_doit: \
1634 MPN_COPY (_destp, _sp, _dests); \
1635 _destp[0] &= ~(_ulp - 1); \
1636 } \
1637 else if (MPFR_UNLIKELY (_sb == 0)) \
1638 { /* Middle of two consecutive representable numbers */ \
1639 MIDDLE_HANDLER; \
1640 } \
1641 else \
1642 { \
1643 if (0) \
1644 goto addoneulp_doit; /* dummy code to avoid warning */ \
1645 addoneulp: \
1646 inexact = sign; \
1647 addoneulp_doit: \
1648 if (MPFR_UNLIKELY (mpn_add_1 (_destp, _sp, _dests, _ulp))) \
1649 { \
1650 _destp[_dests - 1] = MPFR_LIMB_HIGHBIT; \
1651 OVERFLOW_HANDLER; \
1652 } \
1653 _destp[0] &= ~(_ulp - 1); \
1654 } \
1655 } \
1656 else \
1657 { /* Directed rounding mode */ \
1658 if (MPFR_IS_LIKE_RNDZ (rnd, MPFR_IS_NEG_SIGN (sign))) \
1659 goto trunc; \
1660 else if (MPFR_UNLIKELY ((_sb | _rb) == 0)) \
1661 { \
1662 inexact = 0; \
1663 goto trunc_doit; \
1664 } \
1665 else \
1666 goto addoneulp; \
1667 } \
1668 } \
1669 } while (0)
1670
1671/*
1672 * Round mantissa (srcp, sprec) to mpfr_t dest using rounding mode rnd
1673 * assuming dest's sign is sign.
1674 * Execute OVERFLOW_HANDLER in case of overflow when rounding.
1675 */
1676#define MPFR_RNDRAW(inexact, dest, srcp, sprec, rnd, sign, OVERFLOW_HANDLER) \
1677 MPFR_RNDRAW_GEN (inexact, dest, srcp, sprec, rnd, sign, \
1678 if ((_sp[0] & _ulp) == 0) \
1679 { \
1680 inexact = -sign; \
1681 goto trunc_doit; \
1682 } \
1683 else \
1684 goto addoneulp; \
1685 , OVERFLOW_HANDLER)
1686
1687/*
1688 * Round mantissa (srcp, sprec) to mpfr_t dest using rounding mode rnd
1689 * assuming dest's sign is sign.
1690 * Execute OVERFLOW_HANDLER in case of overflow when rounding.
1691 * Set inexact to +/- MPFR_EVEN_INEX in case of even rounding.
1692 */
1693#define MPFR_RNDRAW_EVEN(inexact, dest, srcp, sprec, rnd, sign, \
1694 OVERFLOW_HANDLER) \
1695 MPFR_RNDRAW_GEN (inexact, dest, srcp, sprec, rnd, sign, \
1696 if ((_sp[0] & _ulp) == 0) \
1697 { \
1698 inexact = -MPFR_EVEN_INEX * sign; \
1699 goto trunc_doit; \
1700 } \
1701 else \
1702 { \
1703 inexact = MPFR_EVEN_INEX * sign; \
1704 goto addoneulp_doit; \
1705 } \
1706 , OVERFLOW_HANDLER)
1707
1708/* Return TRUE if b is non singular and we can round it to precision 'prec'
1709 and determine the ternary value, with rounding mode 'rnd', and with
1710 error at most 'error' */
1711#define MPFR_CAN_ROUND(b,err,prec,rnd) \
1712 (!MPFR_IS_SINGULAR (b) && mpfr_round_p (MPFR_MANT (b), MPFR_LIMB_SIZE (b), \
1713 (err), (prec) + ((rnd)==MPFR_RNDN)))
1714
1715/* Copy the sign and the significand, and handle the exponent in exp. */
1716#define MPFR_SETRAW(inexact,dest,src,exp,rnd) \
1717 if (dest != src) \
1718 { \
1719 MPFR_SET_SIGN (dest, MPFR_SIGN (src)); \
1720 if (MPFR_PREC (dest) == MPFR_PREC (src)) \
1721 { \
1722 MPN_COPY (MPFR_MANT (dest), MPFR_MANT (src), \
1723 MPFR_LIMB_SIZE (src)); \
1724 inexact = 0; \
1725 } \
1726 else \
1727 { \
1728 MPFR_RNDRAW (inexact, dest, MPFR_MANT (src), MPFR_PREC (src), \
1729 rnd, MPFR_SIGN (src), exp++); \
1730 } \
1731 } \
1732 else \
1733 inexact = 0;
1734
1735/* TODO: fix this description (see round_near_x.c). */
1736/* Assuming that the function has a Taylor expansion which looks like:
1737 y=o(f(x)) = o(v + g(x)) with |g(x)| <= 2^(EXP(v)-err)
1738 we can quickly set y to v if x is small (ie err > prec(y)+1) in most
1739 cases. It assumes that f(x) is not representable exactly as a FP number.
1740 v must not be a singular value (NAN, INF or ZERO); usual values are
1741 v=1 or v=x.
1742
1743 y is the destination (a mpfr_t), v the value to set (a mpfr_t),
1744 err1+err2 with err2 <= 3 the error term (mpfr_exp_t's), dir (an int) is
1745 the direction of the committed error (if dir = 0, it rounds toward 0,
1746 if dir=1, it rounds away from 0), rnd the rounding mode.
1747
1748 It returns from the function a ternary value in case of success.
1749 If you want to free something, you must fill the "extra" field
1750 in consequences, otherwise put nothing in it.
1751
1752 The test is less restrictive than necessary, but the function
1753 will finish the check itself.
1754
1755 Note: err1 + err2 is allowed to overflow as mpfr_exp_t, but it must give
1756 its real value as mpfr_uexp_t.
1757*/
1758#define MPFR_FAST_COMPUTE_IF_SMALL_INPUT(y,v,err1,err2,dir,rnd,extra) \
1759 do { \
1760 mpfr_ptr _y = (y); \
1761 mpfr_exp_t _err1 = (err1); \
1762 mpfr_exp_t _err2 = (err2); \
1763 if (_err1 > 0) \
1764 { \
1765 mpfr_uexp_t _err = (mpfr_uexp_t) _err1 + _err2; \
1766 if (MPFR_UNLIKELY (_err > MPFR_PREC (_y) + 1)) \
1767 { \
1768 int _inexact = mpfr_round_near_x (_y,(v),_err,(dir),(rnd)); \
1769 if (_inexact != 0) \
1770 { \
1771 extra; \
1772 return _inexact; \
1773 } \
1774 } \
1775 } \
1776 } while (0)
1777
1778/* Variant, to be called somewhere after MPFR_SAVE_EXPO_MARK. This variant
1779 is needed when there are some computations before or when some non-zero
1780 real constant is used, such as __gmpfr_one for mpfr_cos. */
1781#define MPFR_SMALL_INPUT_AFTER_SAVE_EXPO(y,v,err1,err2,dir,rnd,expo,extra) \
1782 do { \
1783 mpfr_ptr _y = (y); \
1784 mpfr_exp_t _err1 = (err1); \
1785 mpfr_exp_t _err2 = (err2); \
1786 if (_err1 > 0) \
1787 { \
1788 mpfr_uexp_t _err = (mpfr_uexp_t) _err1 + _err2; \
1789 if (MPFR_UNLIKELY (_err > MPFR_PREC (_y) + 1)) \
1790 { \
1791 int _inexact; \
1792 MPFR_CLEAR_FLAGS (); \
1793 _inexact = mpfr_round_near_x (_y,(v),_err,(dir),(rnd)); \
1794 if (_inexact != 0) \
1795 { \
1796 extra; \
1797 MPFR_SAVE_EXPO_UPDATE_FLAGS (expo, __gmpfr_flags); \
1798 MPFR_SAVE_EXPO_FREE (expo); \
1799 return mpfr_check_range (_y, _inexact, (rnd)); \
1800 } \
1801 } \
1802 } \
1803 } while (0)
1804
1805
1806/******************************************************
1807 ***************** Ziv loop macros ******************
1808 ******************************************************/
1809
1810/* To safely increase some precision, detecting integer overflows.
1811 This macro is particularly useful when determining the initial
1812 working precision before Ziv's loop. P is a precision, X is an
1813 arbitrary nonnegative integer.
1814 Note: On 2012-02-23, the MPFR_PREC_MAX value has been decreased
1815 by 256 from the maximum value representable in the mpfr_prec_t
1816 type, in order to avoid some integer overflows when this macro
1817 is not used (if the result is larger than MPFR_PREC_MAX, this
1818 should be detected with a later assertion, e.g. in mpfr_init2).
1819 But this change is mainly for existing code that has not been
1820 updated yet. So, it is advised to always use MPFR_ADD_PREC if
1821 the result can be larger than MPFR_PREC_MAX. */
1822#define MPFR_ADD_PREC(P,X) \
1823 (MPFR_ASSERTN ((X) <= MPFR_PREC_MAX - (P)), (P) + (X))
1824
1825#ifndef MPFR_USE_LOGGING
1826
1827#define MPFR_ZIV_DECL(_x) mpfr_prec_t _x
1828#define MPFR_ZIV_INIT(_x, _p) (_x) = GMP_NUMB_BITS
1829#define MPFR_ZIV_NEXT(_x, _p) ((_p) = MPFR_ADD_PREC (_p, _x), (_x) = (_p)/2)
1830#define MPFR_ZIV_FREE(x)
1831
1832#else
1833
1834/* The following test on glibc is there mainly for Darwin (Mac OS X), to
1835 obtain a better error message. The real test should have been a test
1836 concerning nested functions in gcc, which are disabled by default on
1837 Darwin; but it is not possible to do that without a configure test. */
1838# if defined (__cplusplus) || !(__MPFR_GNUC(3,0) && __MPFR_GLIBC(2,0))
1839# error "Logging not supported (needs gcc >= 3.0 and GNU C Library >= 2.0)."
1840# endif
1841
1842/* Use LOGGING */
1843
1844/* Note: the mpfr_log_level >= 0 below avoids to take into account
1845 Ziv loops used by the MPFR functions called by the mpfr_fprintf
1846 in LOG_PRINT. */
1847
1848#define MPFR_ZIV_DECL(_x) \
1849 mpfr_prec_t _x; \
1850 int _x ## _cpt = 1; \
1851 static unsigned long _x ## _loop = 0, _x ## _bad = 0; \
1852 static const char *_x ## _fname = __func__; \
1853 auto void __attribute__ ((destructor)) x ## _f (void); \
1854 void __attribute__ ((destructor)) x ## _f (void) { \
1855 if (_x ## _loop != 0 && (MPFR_LOG_STAT_F & mpfr_log_type)) { \
1856 fprintf (mpfr_log_file, \
1857 "%s: Ziv failed %2.2f%% (%lu bad cases / %lu calls)\n", \
1858 _x ## _fname, (double) 100.0 * _x ## _bad / _x ## _loop, \
1859 _x ## _bad, _x ## _loop ); \
1860 if (mpfr_log_flush) \
1861 fflush (mpfr_log_file); \
1862 } \
1863 }
1864
1865#define MPFR_ZIV_INIT(_x, _p) \
1866 do \
1867 { \
1868 (_x) = GMP_NUMB_BITS; \
1869 if (mpfr_log_level >= 0) \
1870 _x ## _loop ++; \
1871 LOG_PRINT (MPFR_LOG_BADCASE_F, "%s:ZIV 1st prec=%Pd\n", \
1872 __func__, (mpfr_prec_t) (_p)); \
1873 } \
1874 while (0)
1875
1876#define MPFR_ZIV_NEXT(_x, _p) \
1877 do \
1878 { \
1879 (_p) = MPFR_ADD_PREC (_p, _x); \
1880 (_x) = (_p) / 2; \
1881 if (mpfr_log_level >= 0) \
1882 _x ## _bad += (_x ## _cpt == 1); \
1883 _x ## _cpt ++; \
1884 LOG_PRINT (MPFR_LOG_BADCASE_F, "%s:ZIV new prec=%Pd\n", \
1885 __func__, (mpfr_prec_t) (_p)); \
1886 } \
1887 while (0)
1888
1889#define MPFR_ZIV_FREE(_x) \
1890 do \
1891 if (_x ## _cpt > 1) \
1892 LOG_PRINT (MPFR_LOG_BADCASE_F, "%s:ZIV %d loops\n", \
1893 __func__, _x ## _cpt); \
1894 while (0)
1895
1896#endif
1897
1898
1899/******************************************************
1900 ****************** Logging macros ******************
1901 ******************************************************/
1902
1903/* The different kind of LOG */
1904#define MPFR_LOG_INPUT_F 1
1905#define MPFR_LOG_OUTPUT_F 2
1906#define MPFR_LOG_INTERNAL_F 4
1907#define MPFR_LOG_TIME_F 8
1908#define MPFR_LOG_BADCASE_F 16
1909#define MPFR_LOG_MSG_F 32
1910#define MPFR_LOG_STAT_F 64
1911
1912#ifdef MPFR_USE_LOGGING
1913
1914/* Check if we can support this feature */
1915# ifdef MPFR_USE_THREAD_SAFE
1916# error "Enable either `Logging' or `thread-safe', not both"
1917# endif
1918# if !__MPFR_GNUC(3,0)
1919# error "Logging not supported (GCC >= 3.0)"
1920# endif
1921
1922#if defined (__cplusplus)
1923extern "C" {
1924#endif
1925
1926__MPFR_DECLSPEC extern FILE *mpfr_log_file;
1927__MPFR_DECLSPEC extern int mpfr_log_flush;
1928__MPFR_DECLSPEC extern int mpfr_log_type;
1929__MPFR_DECLSPEC extern int mpfr_log_level;
1930__MPFR_DECLSPEC extern int mpfr_log_current;
1931__MPFR_DECLSPEC extern mpfr_prec_t mpfr_log_prec;
1932
1933#if defined (__cplusplus)
1934 }
1935#endif
1936
1937/* LOG_PRINT calls mpfr_fprintf on mpfr_log_file with logging disabled
1938 (recursive logging is not wanted and freezes MPFR). */
1939#define LOG_PRINT(type, format, ...) \
1940 do \
1941 if ((mpfr_log_type & (type)) && mpfr_log_current <= mpfr_log_level) \
1942 { \
1943 int old_level = mpfr_log_level; \
1944 mpfr_log_level = -1; /* disable logging in mpfr_fprintf */ \
1945 __gmpfr_cache_const_pi = __gmpfr_logging_pi; \
1946 __gmpfr_cache_const_log2 = __gmpfr_logging_log2; \
1947 mpfr_fprintf (mpfr_log_file, format, __VA_ARGS__); \
1948 if (mpfr_log_flush) \
1949 fflush (mpfr_log_file); \
1950 mpfr_log_level = old_level; \
1951 __gmpfr_cache_const_pi = __gmpfr_normal_pi; \
1952 __gmpfr_cache_const_log2 = __gmpfr_normal_log2; \
1953 } \
1954 while (0)
1955
1956#define MPFR_LOG_VAR(x) \
1957 LOG_PRINT (MPFR_LOG_INTERNAL_F, "%s.%d:%s[%#Pu]=%.*Rg\n", __func__, \
1958 __LINE__, #x, mpfr_get_prec (x), mpfr_log_prec, x)
1959
1960#define MPFR_LOG_MSG2(format, ...) \
1961 LOG_PRINT (MPFR_LOG_MSG_F, "%s.%d: "format, __func__, __LINE__, __VA_ARGS__)
1962#define MPFR_LOG_MSG(x) MPFR_LOG_MSG2 x
1963
1964#define MPFR_LOG_BEGIN2(format, ...) \
1965 mpfr_log_current ++; \
1966 LOG_PRINT (MPFR_LOG_INPUT_F, "%s:IN "format"\n", __func__, __VA_ARGS__); \
1967 if ((MPFR_LOG_TIME_F & mpfr_log_type) && \
1968 (mpfr_log_current <= mpfr_log_level)) \
1969 __gmpfr_log_time = mpfr_get_cputime ();
1970#define MPFR_LOG_BEGIN(x) \
1971 int __gmpfr_log_time = 0; \
1972 MPFR_LOG_BEGIN2 x
1973
1974#define MPFR_LOG_END2(format, ...) \
1975 LOG_PRINT (MPFR_LOG_TIME_F, "%s:TIM %dms\n", __mpfr_log_fname, \
1976 mpfr_get_cputime () - __gmpfr_log_time); \
1977 LOG_PRINT (MPFR_LOG_OUTPUT_F, "%s:OUT "format"\n", __mpfr_log_fname, \
1978 __VA_ARGS__); \
1979 mpfr_log_current --;
1980#define MPFR_LOG_END(x) \
1981 static const char *__mpfr_log_fname = __func__; \
1982 MPFR_LOG_END2 x
1983
1984#define MPFR_LOG_FUNC(begin,end) \
1985 static const char *__mpfr_log_fname = __func__; \
1986 auto void __mpfr_log_cleanup (int *time); \
1987 void __mpfr_log_cleanup (int *time) { \
1988 int __gmpfr_log_time = *time; \
1989 MPFR_LOG_END2 end; } \
1990 int __gmpfr_log_time __attribute__ ((cleanup (__mpfr_log_cleanup))); \
1991 __gmpfr_log_time = 0; \
1992 MPFR_LOG_BEGIN2 begin
1993
1994#else /* MPFR_USE_LOGGING */
1995
1996/* Define void macro for logging */
1997
1998#define MPFR_LOG_VAR(x)
1999#define MPFR_LOG_BEGIN(x)
2000#define MPFR_LOG_END(x)
2001#define MPFR_LOG_MSG(x)
2002#define MPFR_LOG_FUNC(x,y)
2003
2004#endif /* MPFR_USE_LOGGING */

2006
2007/**************************************************************
2008 ************ Group Initialize Functions Macros *************
2009 **************************************************************/
2010
2011#ifndef MPFR_GROUP_STATIC_SIZE
2012# define MPFR_GROUP_STATIC_SIZE 16
2013#endif
2014
2015struct mpfr_group_t {
2016 size_t alloc;
2017 mp_limb_t *mant;
2018 mp_limb_t tab[MPFR_GROUP_STATIC_SIZE];
2019};
2020
2021#define MPFR_GROUP_DECL(g) struct mpfr_group_t g
2022#define MPFR_GROUP_CLEAR(g) do { \
2023 MPFR_LOG_MSG (("GROUP_CLEAR: ptr = 0x%lX, size = %lu\n", \
2024 (unsigned long) (g).mant, \
2025 (unsigned long) (g).alloc)); \
2026 if ((g).alloc != 0) { \
2027 MPFR_ASSERTD ((g).mant != (g).tab); \
2028 mpfr_free_func ((g).mant, (g).alloc); \
2029 }} while (0)
2030
2031#define MPFR_GROUP_INIT_TEMPLATE(g, prec, num, handler) do { \
2032 mpfr_prec_t _prec = (prec); \
2033 mp_size_t _size; \
2034 MPFR_ASSERTD (_prec >= MPFR_PREC_MIN); \
2035 if (MPFR_UNLIKELY (_prec > MPFR_PREC_MAX)) \
2036 mpfr_abort_prec_max (); \
2037 _size = MPFR_PREC2LIMBS (_prec); \
2038 if (_size * (num) > MPFR_GROUP_STATIC_SIZE) \
2039 { \
2040 (g).alloc = (num) * _size * sizeof (mp_limb_t); \
2041 (g).mant = (mp_limb_t *) mpfr_allocate_func ((g).alloc); \
2042 } \
2043 else \
2044 { \
2045 (g).alloc = 0; \
2046 (g).mant = (g).tab; \
2047 } \
2048 MPFR_LOG_MSG (("GROUP_INIT: ptr = 0x%lX, size = %lu\n", \
2049 (unsigned long) (g).mant, (unsigned long) (g).alloc)); \
2050 handler; \
2051 } while (0)
2052#define MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, n, x) \
2053 MPFR_TMP_INIT1 ((g).mant + _size * (n), x, _prec)
2054
2055#define MPFR_GROUP_INIT_1(g, prec, x) \
2056 MPFR_GROUP_INIT_TEMPLATE(g, prec, 1, MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 0, x))
2057#define MPFR_GROUP_INIT_2(g, prec, x, y) \
2058 MPFR_GROUP_INIT_TEMPLATE(g, prec, 2, \
2059 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 0, x);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 1, y))
2060#define MPFR_GROUP_INIT_3(g, prec, x, y, z) \
2061 MPFR_GROUP_INIT_TEMPLATE(g, prec, 3, \
2062 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 0, x);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 1, y); \
2063 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 2, z))
2064#define MPFR_GROUP_INIT_4(g, prec, x, y, z, t) \
2065 MPFR_GROUP_INIT_TEMPLATE(g, prec, 4, \
2066 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 0, x);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 1, y); \
2067 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 2, z);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 3, t))
2068#define MPFR_GROUP_INIT_5(g, prec, x, y, z, t, a) \
2069 MPFR_GROUP_INIT_TEMPLATE(g, prec, 5, \
2070 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 0, x);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 1, y); \
2071 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 2, z);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 3, t); \
2072 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 4, a))
2073#define MPFR_GROUP_INIT_6(g, prec, x, y, z, t, a, b) \
2074 MPFR_GROUP_INIT_TEMPLATE(g, prec, 6, \
2075 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 0, x);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 1, y); \
2076 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 2, z);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 3, t); \
2077 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 4, a);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 5, b))
2078
2079#define MPFR_GROUP_REPREC_TEMPLATE(g, prec, num, handler) do { \
2080 mpfr_prec_t _prec = (prec); \
2081 size_t _oalloc = (g).alloc; \
2082 mp_size_t _size; \
2083 MPFR_LOG_MSG (("GROUP_REPREC: oldptr = 0x%lX, oldsize = %lu\n", \
2084 (unsigned long) (g).mant, (unsigned long) _oalloc)); \
2085 MPFR_ASSERTD (_prec >= MPFR_PREC_MIN); \
2086 if (MPFR_UNLIKELY (_prec > MPFR_PREC_MAX)) \
2087 mpfr_abort_prec_max (); \
2088 _size = MPFR_PREC2LIMBS (_prec); \
2089 (g).alloc = (num) * _size * sizeof (mp_limb_t); \
2090 if (_oalloc == 0) \
2091 (g).mant = (mp_limb_t *) mpfr_allocate_func ((g).alloc); \
2092 else \
2093 (g).mant = (mp_limb_t *) \
2094 mpfr_reallocate_func ((g).mant, _oalloc, (g).alloc); \
2095 MPFR_LOG_MSG (("GROUP_REPREC: newptr = 0x%lX, newsize = %lu\n", \
2096 (unsigned long) (g).mant, (unsigned long) (g).alloc)); \
2097 handler; \
2098 } while (0)
2099
2100#define MPFR_GROUP_REPREC_1(g, prec, x) \
2101 MPFR_GROUP_REPREC_TEMPLATE(g, prec, 1, MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 0, x))
2102#define MPFR_GROUP_REPREC_2(g, prec, x, y) \
2103 MPFR_GROUP_REPREC_TEMPLATE(g, prec, 2, \
2104 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 0, x);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 1, y))
2105#define MPFR_GROUP_REPREC_3(g, prec, x, y, z) \
2106 MPFR_GROUP_REPREC_TEMPLATE(g, prec, 3, \
2107 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 0, x);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 1, y); \
2108 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 2, z))
2109#define MPFR_GROUP_REPREC_4(g, prec, x, y, z, t) \
2110 MPFR_GROUP_REPREC_TEMPLATE(g, prec, 4, \
2111 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 0, x);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 1, y); \
2112 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 2, z);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 3, t))
2113#define MPFR_GROUP_REPREC_5(g, prec, x, y, z, t, a) \
2114 MPFR_GROUP_REPREC_TEMPLATE(g, prec, 5, \
2115 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 0, x);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 1, y); \
2116 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 2, z);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 3, t); \
2117 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 4, a))
2118#define MPFR_GROUP_REPREC_6(g, prec, x, y, z, t, a, b) \
2119 MPFR_GROUP_REPREC_TEMPLATE(g, prec, 6, \
2120 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 0, x);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 1, y); \
2121 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 2, z);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 3, t); \
2122 MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 4, a);MPFR_GROUP_TINIT(g, 5, b))
2123

2276#endif

2279# undef mpz_init
2280# undef mpz_init2

2282# undef mpz_init_set_ui
2283# undef mpz_init_set

2288# define mpz_init_set(a,b) do { mpz_init (a); mpz_set (a, b); } while (0)

2292/******************************************************
2293 ******** Compute LOG2(LOG2(MPFR_PREC_MAX)) *********
2294 ******************************************************/
2295
2296#if _MPFR_PREC_FORMAT == 1
2297# define MPFR_PREC_MAX_TEMP USHRT_MAX
2298#elif _MPFR_PREC_FORMAT == 2
2299# define MPFR_PREC_MAX_TEMP UINT_MAX
2300#elif _MPFR_PREC_FORMAT == 3
2301# define MPFR_PREC_MAX_TEMP ULONG_MAX
2302#else
2303# error "Invalid MPFR Prec format"
2304#endif
2305
2306/* Note: In the constants below, it is sufficient to use the suffix U.
2307 * A large enough unsigned type will be chosen automatically, but the
2308 * exact type doesn't matter here.
2309 */
2310
2311#if MPFR_PREC_MAX_TEMP == 255U
2312# define MPFR_PREC_BITS 8
2313# define MPFR_LOG2_PREC_BITS 3
2314#elif MPFR_PREC_MAX_TEMP == 65535U
2315# define MPFR_PREC_BITS 16
2316# define MPFR_LOG2_PREC_BITS 4
2317#elif MPFR_PREC_MAX_TEMP == 4294967295U
2318# define MPFR_PREC_BITS 32
2319# define MPFR_LOG2_PREC_BITS 5
2320#elif MPFR_PREC_MAX_TEMP == 18446744073709551615U
2321# define MPFR_PREC_BITS 64
2322# define MPFR_LOG2_PREC_BITS 6
2323#else
2324# error "Unsupported MPFR_PREC_MAX_TEMP value"
2325#endif

2356/******************************************************
2357 ***************** Unbounded Floats *****************
2358 ******************************************************/
2359
2360#if defined (__cplusplus)
2361extern "C" {
2362#endif
2363
2364/* An UBF is like a MPFR number, but with an additional mpz_t member,
2365 which is assumed to be present (with a value in it) when the usual
2366 exponent field has the value MPFR_EXP_UBF. The goal of this compatible
2367 representation is to easily be able to support UBF in "normal" code
2368 and hopefully avoid aliasing issues at the same time. And code that
2369 accepts UBF in input should also accept mpfr_t as a consequence; this
2370 makes mpfr_t to UBF conversion unnecessary.
2371 When an input of a public function is a UBF, the semantic remains
2372 internal to MPFR and can change in the future.
2373 Note that functions used for logging need to support UBF (currently
2374 done by printing that a number is a UBF, as it may be difficult to
2375 do more without significant changes). */
2376
2377typedef struct {
2378 mpfr_prec_t _mpfr_prec;
2379 mpfr_sign_t _mpfr_sign;
2380 mpfr_exp_t _mpfr_exp;
2381 mp_limb_t *_mpfr_d;
2382 mpz_t _mpfr_zexp;
2383} __mpfr_ubf_struct;
2384
2385typedef __mpfr_ubf_struct mpfr_ubf_t[1];
2386typedef __mpfr_ubf_struct *mpfr_ubf_ptr;
2387
2388__MPFR_DECLSPEC void mpfr_ubf_mul_exact (mpfr_ubf_ptr,
2389 mpfr_srcptr, mpfr_srcptr);
2390__MPFR_DECLSPEC int mpfr_ubf_exp_less_p (mpfr_srcptr, mpfr_srcptr);
2391__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_exp_t mpfr_ubf_zexp2exp (mpz_ptr);
2392__MPFR_DECLSPEC mpfr_exp_t mpfr_ubf_diff_exp (mpfr_srcptr, mpfr_srcptr);
2393
2394#if defined (__cplusplus)
2395}
2396#endif
2397
2398#define MPFR_ZEXP(x) \
2399 ((void) (x)->_mpfr_exp /* to check that x has a correct type */, \
2400 ((mpfr_ubf_ptr) (x))->_mpfr_zexp)
2401
2402#define MPFR_UBF_CLEAR_EXP(x) \
2403 ((void) (MPFR_IS_UBF (x) && (mpz_clear (MPFR_ZEXP (x)), 0)))
2404
2405#endif /* __MPFR_IMPL_H__ */
